enabled: ${8:true} # not required. Interface link status. If the value is I(True) the interface state will be enabled, else if value is I(False) interface will be in disable (shutdown) state.
speed: ${9:undefined} # not required. This option configures autoneg and speed/duplex/flowcontrol for the interface given in C(name) option.

rx_rate: ${10:undefined} # not required. Receiver rate in bits per second (bps) for the interface given in C(name) option.,This is state check parameter only.,Supports conditionals, see L(Conditionals in Networking Modules,../network/user_guide/network_working_with_command_output.html)

authorize: ${11|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

auth_pass: ${12:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

state: ${13|present,absent,up,down|} # not required. choices: present;absent;up;down. State of the Interface configuration, C(up) means present and operationally up and C(down) means present and operationally C(down)
aggregate: ${14:undefined} # not required. List of Interfaces definitions. Each of the entry in aggregate list should define name of interface C(name) and other options as required.

eos_l2_interface.description: Manage L2 interfaces on Arista EOS network devices.
body: eos_l2_interface:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the interface

authorize: ${2|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
mode: ${3|access,trunk|} # not required. choices: access;trunk. Mode in which interface needs to be configured.
access_vlan: ${4:undefined} # not required. Configure given VLAN in access port. If C(mode=access), used as the access VLAN ID.
native_vlan: ${5:undefined} # not required. Native VLAN to be configured in trunk port. If C(mode=trunk), used as the trunk native VLAN ID.
trunk_allowed_vlans: ${6:undefined} # not required. List of allowed VLANs in a given trunk port. If C(mode=trunk), these are the ONLY VLANs that will be configured on the trunk, i.e. C(2-10,15).

auth_pass: ${7:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
state: ${8|present,absent,unconfigured|} # not required. choices: present;absent;unconfigured. Manage the state of the Layer-2 Interface configuration.

provider: ${9:null} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,A dict object containing connection details.
aggregate: ${10:undefined} # not required. List of Layer-2 interface definitions.

eos_l3_interface.description: Manage L3 interfaces on Arista EOS network devices.
body: eos_l3_interface:

authorize: ${1|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

ipv4: ${2:undefined} # not required. IPv4 address to be set for the L3 interface mentioned in I(name) option. The address format is <ipv4 address>/<mask>, the mask is number in range 0-32 eg. 192.168.0.1/24

auth_pass: ${3:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

ipv6: ${4:undefined} # not required. IPv6 address to be set for the L3 interface mentioned in I(name) option. The address format is <ipv6 address>/<mask>, the mask is number in range 0-128 eg. fd5d:12c9:2201:1::1/64
state: ${5|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the L3 interface configuration. It indicates if the configuration should be present or absent on remote device.

provider: ${6:null} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,A dict object containing connection details.
aggregate: ${7:undefined} # not required. List of L3 interfaces definitions. Each of the entry in aggregate list should define name of interface C(name) and a optional C(ipv4) or C(ipv6) address.
name: ${8:undefined} # not required. Name of the L3 interface to be configured eg. ethernet1

eos_system.description: Manage the system attributes on Arista EOS devices
body: eos_system:

name_servers: ${1:undefined} # not required. List of DNS name servers by IP address to use to perform name resolution lookups.  This argument accepts either a list of DNS servers or a list of hashes that configure the name server and VRF name.  See examples.

domain_search: ${2:undefined} # not required. Provides the list of domain suffixes to append to the hostname for the purpose of doing name resolution. This argument accepts a list of names and will be reconciled with the current active configuration on the running node.

domain_name: ${3:undefined} # not required. Configure the IP domain name on the remote device to the provided value. Value should be in the dotted name form and will be appended to the C(hostname) to create a fully-qualified domain name.

auth_pass: ${4:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

lookup_source: ${5:undefined} # not required. Provides one or more source interfaces to use for performing DNS lookups.  The interface provided in C(lookup_source) can only exist in a single VRF.  This argument accepts either a list of interface names or a list of hashes that configure the interface name and VRF name.  See examples.

authorize: ${6|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the configuration values in the device's current active configuration.  When set to I(present), the values should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the values should not be in the device active configuration

provider: ${8:null} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,A dict object containing connection details.
hostname: ${9:undefined} # not required. Configure the device hostname parameter. This option takes an ASCII string value.

eos_user.description: Manage the collection of local users on EOS devices
body: eos_user:
sshkey: ${1:undefined} # not required. Specifies the SSH public key to configure for the given username.  This argument accepts a valid SSH key value.

auth_pass: ${2:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

privilege: ${3:undefined} # not required. The C(privilege) argument configures the privilege level of the user when logged into the system.  This argument accepts integer values in the range of 1 to 15.

purge: ${4:false} # not required. Instructs the module to consider the resource definition absolute.  It will remove any previously configured usernames on the device with the exception of the `admin` user which cannot be deleted per EOS constraints.

role: ${5:undefined} # not required. Configures the role for the username in the device running configuration.  The argument accepts a string value defining the role name.  This argument does not check if the role has been configured on the device.

provider: ${6:null} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,A dict object containing connection details.

configured_password: ${7:undefined} # not required. The password to be configured on the remote Arista EOS device. The password needs to be provided in clear and it will be encrypted on the device. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider password).

authorize: ${8|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
nopassword: ${9:undefined} # not required. Defines the username without assigning a password.  This will allow the user to login to the system without being authenticated by a password.

state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Configures the state of the username definition as it relates to the device operational configuration.  When set to I(present), the username(s) should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the username(s) should not be in the device active configuration

update_password: ${11|on_create,always|} # not required. choices: on_create;always. Since passwords are encrypted in the device running config, this argument will instruct the module when to change the password.  When set to C(always), the password will always be updated in the device and when set to C(on_create) the password will be updated only if the username is created.

aggregate: ${12:undefined} # not required. The set of username objects to be configured on the remote Arista EOS device.  The list entries can either be the username or a hash of username and properties.  This argument is mutually exclusive with the C(username) argument.

name: ${13:undefined} # not required. The username to be configured on the remote Arista EOS device.  This argument accepts a stringv value and is mutually exclusive with the C(aggregate) argument. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider username).

eos_vlan.description: Manage VLANs on Arista EOS network devices
body: eos_vlan:
vlan_id: ${1:undefined} # required. ID of the VLAN.

auth_pass: ${2:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
purge: ${3:false} # not required. Purge VLANs not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
delay: ${4:10} # not required. Delay the play should wait to check for declarative intent params values.
interfaces: ${5:undefined} # not required. List of interfaces that should be associated to the VLAN. The name of interface should be in expanded format and not abbreviated.

provider: ${6:null} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,A dict object containing connection details.

associated_interfaces: ${7:undefined} # not required. This is a intent option and checks the operational state of the for given vlan C(name) for associated interfaces. The name of interface should be in expanded format and not abbreviated. If the value in the C(associated_interfaces) does not match with the operational state of vlan interfaces on device it will result in failure.

authorize: ${8|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
state: ${9|present,absent,active,suspend|} # not required. choices: present;absent;active;suspend. State of the VLAN configuration.
aggregate: ${10:undefined} # not required. List of VLANs definitions.
name: ${11:undefined} # not required. Name of the VLAN.

eos_vrf.description: Manage VRFs on Arista EOS network devices
body: eos_vrf:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the VRF.

auth_pass: ${2:none} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes) with C(become_pass).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
purge: ${3:false} # not required. Purge VRFs not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
delay: ${4:10} # not required. Time in seconds to wait before checking for the operational state on remote device. This wait is applicable for operational state arguments.

interfaces: ${5:undefined} # not required. Identifies the set of interfaces that should be configured in the VRF. Interfaces must be routed interfaces in order to be placed into a VRF. The name of interface should be in expanded format and not abbreviated.

provider: ${6:null} # not required. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,A dict object containing connection details.

associated_interfaces: ${7:undefined} # not required. This is a intent option and checks the operational state of the for given vrf C(name) for associated interfaces. If the value in the C(associated_interfaces) does not match with the operational state of vrf interfaces on device it will result in failure.

authorize: ${8|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. B(Deprecated),Starting with Ansible 2.5 we recommend using C(connection: network_cli) and C(become: yes).,This option is only required if you are using eAPI.,For more information please see the L(EOS Platform Options guide, ../network/user_guide/platform_eos.html).,HORIZONTALLINE,Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
rd: ${9:undefined} # not required. Route distinguisher of the VRF
state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the VRF configuration.
aggregate: ${11:undefined} # not required. List of VRFs definitions

etcd3.description: Set or delete key value pairs from an etcd3 cluster
body: etcd3:
value: ${1:undefined} # required. the information stored
state: ${2:undefined} # required. the state of the value for the key.,can be present or absent
key: ${3:undefined} # required. the key where the information is stored in the cluster
port: ${4:2379} # not required. the port number used to connect to the cluster
host: ${5:localhost} # not required. the IP address of the cluster
execute_lambda:

dry_run: ${1:false} # not required. Do not *actually* invoke the function. A C(DryRun) call will check that the caller has permissions to call the function, especially for checking cross-account permissions.
validate_certs: ${2:yes} # not required. When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.
aws_secret_key: ${3:null} # not required. AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
function_arn: ${4:None} # not required. The name of the function to be invoked

tail_log: ${5:false} # not required. If C(tail_log=true), the result of the task will include the last 4 KB of the CloudWatch log for the function execution. Log tailing only works if you use synchronous invocation C(wait=true). This is usually used for development or testing Lambdas.

wait: ${6:true} # not required. Whether to wait for the function results or not. If I(wait) is false, the task will not return any results. To wait for the Lambda function to complete, set C(wait=true) and the result will be available in the I(output) key.

region: ${7:undefined} # not required. The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)

ec2_url: ${8:null} # not required. Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
aws_access_key: ${9:null} # not required. AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
payload: ${10:[object Object]} # not required. A dictionary in any form to be provided as input to the Lambda function.
security_token: ${11:null} # not required. AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

version_qualifier: ${12:LATEST} # not required. Which version/alias of the function to run. This defaults to the C(LATEST) revision, but can be set to any existing version or alias. See https;//docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/versioning-aliases.html for details.

name: ${13:None} # not required. The name of the function to be invoked. This can only be used for invocations within the calling account. To invoke a function in another account, use I(function_arn) to specify the full ARN.
profile: ${14:null} # not required. Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.

exo_dns_domain.description: Manages domain records on Exoscale DNS API.
body: exo_dns_domain:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the record.
validate_certs: ${2:true} # not required. Validate SSL certs of the Exoscale DNS API.
api_timeout: ${3:10} # not required. HTTP timeout to Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_TIMEOUT) is used as default, when defined.
api_secret: ${4:undefined} # not required. Secret key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_SECRET) is used as default, when defined.
api_key: ${5:undefined} # not required. API key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_KEY) is used as default, when defined.
api_region: ${6:cloudstack} # not required. Name of the ini section in the C(cloustack.ini) file.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_REGION) is used as default, when defined.
state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the resource.

exo_dns_record.description: Manages DNS records on Exoscale DNS.
body: exo_dns_record:
domain: ${1:undefined} # required. Domain the record is related to.
content: ${2:undefined} # not required. Content of the record.,Required if C(state=present) or C(multiple=yes).
validate_certs: ${3:true} # not required. Validate SSL certs of the Exoscale DNS API.
api_timeout: ${4:10} # not required. HTTP timeout to Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_TIMEOUT) is used as default, when defined.
prio: ${5:undefined} # not required. Priority of the record.
ttl: ${6:3600} # not required. TTL of the record in seconds.
api_secret: ${7:undefined} # not required. Secret key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_SECRET) is used as default, when defined.
api_key: ${8:undefined} # not required. API key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_KEY) is used as default, when defined.

multiple: ${9:false} # not required. Whether there are more than one records with similar C(name) and C(record_type).,Only allowed for a few record types, e.g. C(record_type=A), C(record_type=NS) or C(record_type=MX).,C(content) will not be updated, instead it is used as a key to find existing records.
state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the record.

record_type: ${11|A,ALIAS,CNAME,MX,SPF,URL,TXT,NS,SRV,NAPTR,PTR,AAAA,SSHFP,HINFO,POOL|} # not required. choices: A;ALIAS;CNAME;MX;SPF;URL;TXT;NS;SRV;NAPTR;PTR;AAAA;SSHFP;HINFO;POOL. Type of the record.
api_region: ${12:cloudstack} # not required. Name of the ini section in the C(cloustack.ini) file.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_REGION) is used as default, when defined.
name: ${13:} # not required. Name of the record.

expect.description: Executes a command and responds to prompts.
body: expect:

responses: ${1:undefined} # required. Mapping of expected string/regex and string to respond with. If the response is a list, successive matches return successive responses. List functionality is new in 2.1.
command: ${2:undefined} # required. The command module takes command to run.
chdir: ${3:undefined} # not required. Change into this directory before running the command.
creates: ${4:undefined} # not required. A filename, when it already exists, this step will B(not) be run.
echo: ${5:false} # not required. Whether or not to echo out your response strings.
timeout: ${6:30} # not required. Amount of time in seconds to wait for the expected strings.
removes: ${7:undefined} # not required. A filename, when it does not exist, this step will B(not) be run.

facter.description: Runs the discovery program I(facter) on the remote system
body: facter:
fail:
msg: ${1:'Failed as requested from task'} # not required. The customized message used for failing execution. If omitted, fail will simply bail out with a generic message.

fetch.description: Fetches a file from remote nodes
body: fetch:
src: ${1:null} # required. The file on the remote system to fetch. This I(must) be a file, not a directory. Recursive fetching may be supported in a later release.

dest: ${2:null} # required. A directory to save the file into. For example, if the I(dest) directory is C(/backup) a I(src) file named C(/etc/profile) on host C(host.example.com), would be saved into C(/backup/host.example.com/etc/profile)

fail_on_missing: ${3|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. When set to 'yes', the task will fail if the remote file cannot be read for any reason.  Prior to Ansible-2.5, setting this would only fail if the source file was missing.,The default was changed to "yes" in Ansible-2.5.
validate_checksum: ${4|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. Verify that the source and destination checksums match after the files are fetched.

flat: ${5:undefined} # not required. Allows you to override the default behavior of appending hostname/path/to/file to the destination.  If dest ends with '/', it will use the basename of the source file, similar to the copy module. Obviously this is only handy if the filenames are unique.
file:
path: ${1:undefined} # required. path to the file being managed.  Aliases: I(dest), I(name)
selevel: ${2:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

force: ${3:no} # not required. force the creation of the symlinks in two cases: the source file does not exist (but will appear later); the destination exists and is a file (so, we need to unlink the "path" file and create symlink to the "src" file in place of it).

unsafe_writes: ${4:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
recurse: ${5:no} # not required. recursively set the specified file attributes (applies only to state=directory)
serole: ${6:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
owner: ${7:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
setype: ${8:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

src: ${9:undefined} # not required. path of the file to link to (applies only to C(state=link) and C(state=hard)). Will accept absolute, relative and nonexisting paths. Relative paths are not expanded.

mode: ${10:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).

attributes: ${11:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
seuser: ${12:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.

state: ${13|absent,directory,file,hard,link,touch|} # not required. choices: absent;directory;file;hard;link;touch. If C(directory), all immediate subdirectories will be created if they do not exist, since 1.7 they will be created with the supplied permissions. If C(file), the file will NOT be created if it does not exist, see the M(copy) or M(template) module if you want that behavior.  If C(link), the symbolic link will be created or changed. Use C(hard) for hardlinks. If C(absent), directories will be recursively deleted, and files or symlinks will be unlinked. Note that C(absent) will not cause C(file) to fail if the C(path) does not exist as the state did not change. If C(touch) (new in 1.4), an empty file will be created if the C(path) does not exist, while an existing file or directory will receive updated file access and modification times (similar to the way `touch` works from the command line).
group: ${14:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
follow: ${15:yes} # not required. This flag indicates that filesystem links, if they exist, should be followed.,Previous to Ansible 2.5, this was C(no) by default.
filesystem:

fstype: ${1|btrfs,ext2,ext3,ext4,ext4dev,lvm,reiserfs,xfs,vfat|} # required. choices: btrfs;ext2;ext3;ext4;ext4dev;lvm;reiserfs;xfs;vfat. Filesystem type to be created.,reiserfs support was added in 2.2.,lvm support was added in 2.5.,since 2.5, I(dev) can be an image file.,vfat support was added in 2.5
dev: ${2:undefined} # required. Target path to device or image file.

resizefs: ${3:no} # not required. If C(yes), if the block device and filesytem size differ, grow the filesystem into the space.,Supported for C(ext2), C(ext3), C(ext4), C(ext4dev), C(lvm), C(xfs) and C(vfat) filesystems.,XFS Will only grow if mounted.,vFAT will likely fail if fatresize < 1.04.
force: ${4:no} # not required. If C(yes), allows to create new filesystem on devices that already has filesystem.
opts: ${5:undefined} # not required. List of options to be passed to mkfs command.

find.description: Return a list of files based on specific criteria
body: find:
paths: ${1:undefined} # required. List of paths of directories to search. All paths must be fully qualified.

patterns: ${2:*} # not required. One or more (shell or regex) patterns, which type is controlled by C(use_regex) option.,The patterns restrict the list of files to be returned to those whose basenames match at least one of the patterns specified. Multiple patterns can be specified using a list.
hidden: ${3|no,yes|} # not required. choices: no;yes. Set this to true to include hidden files, otherwise they'll be ignored.
recurse: ${4|no,yes|} # not required. choices: no;yes. If target is a directory, recursively descend into the directory looking for files.

size: ${5:undefined} # not required. Select files whose size is equal to or greater than the specified size. Use a negative size to find files equal to or less than the specified size. Unqualified values are in bytes, but b, k, m, g, and t can be appended to specify bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, gigabytes, and terabytes, respectively. Size is not evaluated for directories.
contains: ${6:undefined} # not required. One or more regex patterns which should be matched against the file content.
get_checksum: ${7|no,yes|} # not required. choices: no;yes. Set this to true to retrieve a file's sha1 checksum.
use_regex: ${8|no,yes|} # not required. choices: no;yes. If false the patterns are file globs (shell) if true they are python regexes.

age: ${9:undefined} # not required. Select files whose age is equal to or greater than the specified time. Use a negative age to find files equal to or less than the specified time. You can choose seconds, minutes, hours, days, or weeks by specifying the first letter of any of those words (e.g., "1w").
follow: ${10|no,yes|} # not required. choices: no;yes. Set this to true to follow symlinks in path for systems with python 2.6+.
file_type: ${11|any,directory,file,link|} # not required. choices: any;directory;file;link. Type of file to select.,The 'link' and 'any' choices were added in version 2.3.
age_stamp: ${12|atime,ctime,mtime|} # not required. choices: atime;ctime;mtime. Choose the file property against which we compare age.

excludes: ${13:null} # not required. One or more (shell or regex) patterns, which type is controlled by C(use_regex) option.,Excludes is a patterns should not be returned in list. Multiple patterns can be specified using a list.
firewalld:

state: ${1|enabled,disabled,present,absent|} # required. choices: enabled;disabled;present;absent. Enable or disable a setting. For ports: Should this port accept(enabled) or reject(disabled) connections. The states "present" and "absent" can only be used in zone level operations (i.e. when no other parameters but zone and state are set).
interface: ${2:null} # not required. The interface you would like to add/remove to/from a zone in firewalld
rich_rule: ${3:null} # not required. Rich rule to add/remove to/from firewalld.
port: ${4:null} # not required. Name of a port or port range to add/remove to/from firewalld. Must be in the form PORT/PROTOCOL or PORT-PORT/PROTOCOL for port ranges.
masquerade: ${5:null} # not required. The masquerade setting you would like to enable/disable to/from zones within firewalld
immediate: ${6:false} # not required. Should this configuration be applied immediately, if set as permanent

permanent: ${7:null} # not required. Should this configuration be in the running firewalld configuration or persist across reboots. As of Ansible version 2.3, permanent operations can operate on firewalld configs when it's not running (requires firewalld >= 3.0.9). (NOTE: If this is false, immediate is assumed true.)

zone: ${8|work,drop,internal,external,trusted,home,dmz,public,block|} # not required. choices: work;drop;internal;external;trusted;home;dmz;public;block. The firewalld zone to add/remove to/from (NOTE: default zone can be configured per system but "public" is default from upstream. Available choices can be extended based on per-system configs, listed here are "out of the box" defaults).
timeout: ${9:0} # not required. The amount of time the rule should be in effect for when non-permanent.
source: ${10:null} # not required. The source/network you would like to add/remove to/from firewalld
service: ${11:null} # not required. Name of a service to add/remove to/from firewalld - service must be listed in output of firewall-cmd --get-services.

flowadm.description: Manage bandwidth resource control and priority for protocols, services and zones on Solaris/illumos systems
body: flowadm:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. - A flow is defined as a set of attributes based on Layer 3 and Layer 4 headers, which can be used to identify a protocol, service, or a zone.

dsfield: ${2:undefined} # not required. - Identifies the 8-bit differentiated services field (as defined in RFC 2474). The optional dsfield_mask is used to state the bits of interest in the differentiated services field when comparing with the dsfield value. Both values must be in hexadecimal.
local_port: ${3:undefined} # not required. Identifies a service specified by the local port.
transport: ${4:undefined} # not required. - Specifies a Layer 4 protocol to be used. It is typically used in combination with I(local_port) to identify the service that needs special attention.

maxbw: ${5:undefined} # not required. - Sets the full duplex bandwidth for the flow. The bandwidth is specified as an integer with one of the scale suffixes(K, M, or G for Kbps, Mbps, and Gbps). If no units are specified, the input value will be read as Mbps.
priority: ${6|low,medium,high|} # not required. choices: low;medium;high. Sets the relative priority for the flow.
link: ${7:undefined} # not required. Specifiies a link to configure flow on.
local_ip: ${8:undefined} # not required. Identifies a network flow by the local IP address.
remote_ip: ${9:undefined} # not required. Identifies a network flow by the remote IP address.
state: ${10|absent,present,resetted|} # not required. choices: absent;present;resetted. Create/delete/enable/disable an IP address on the network interface.
temporary: ${11|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Specifies that the configured flow is temporary. Temporary flows do not persist across reboots.

flowdock.description: Send a message to a flowdock
body: flowdock:
type: ${1|inbox,chat|} # required. choices: inbox;chat. Whether to post to 'inbox' or 'chat'
token: ${2:undefined} # required. API token.
msg: ${3:undefined} # required. Content of the message
validate_certs: ${4|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
from_address: ${5:undefined} # not required. (inbox only - required) Email address of the message sender
from_name: ${6:undefined} # not required. (inbox only) Name of the message sender
tags: ${7:undefined} # not required. tags of the message, separated by commas
subject: ${8:undefined} # not required. (inbox only - required) Subject line of the message
external_user_name: ${9:undefined} # not required. (chat only - required) Name of the "user" sending the message
reply_to: ${10:undefined} # not required. (inbox only) Email address for replies
link: ${11:undefined} # not required. (inbox only) Link associated with the message. This will be used to link the message subject in Team Inbox.
project: ${12:undefined} # not required. (inbox only) Human readable identifier for more detailed message categorization
source: ${13:undefined} # not required. (inbox only - required) Human readable identifier of the application that uses the Flowdock API
fmgr_script:
adom: ${1:undefined} # required. The administrative domain (admon) the configuration belongs to
script_name: ${2:undefined} # required. The name of the script.
host: ${3:undefined} # required. The FortiManager's Address.
username: ${4:undefined} # required. The username to log into the FortiManager

state: ${5|present,execute,delete|} # not required. choices: present;execute;delete. The desired state of the specified object.,present - will create a script.,execute - execute the scipt.,delete - delete the script.
password: ${6:undefined} # not required. The password associated with the username account.
vdom: ${7:undefined} # not required. The virtual domain (vdom) the configuration belongs to
script_package: ${8:undefined} # not required. (datasource) Policy package object to run the script against
script_target: ${9:undefined} # not required. The target of the script to be run.
script_type: ${10:undefined} # not required. The type of script (CLI or TCL).
script_content: ${11:undefined} # not required. The script content that will be executed.
script_scope: ${12:undefined} # not required. (datasource) The devices that the script will run on, can have both device member and device group member.
script_description: ${13:undefined} # not required. The description of the script.
foreman:
server_url: ${1:undefined} # required. URL of Foreman server.
params: ${2:undefined} # required. Parameters associated to the entity resource to set or edit in dictionary format (e.g. name, description).
username: ${3:undefined} # required. Username on Foreman server.
entity: ${4:undefined} # required. The Foreman resource that the action will be performed on (e.g. organization, host).
password: ${5:undefined} # required. Password for user accessing Foreman server.
fortios_address:
state: ${1|present,absent|} # required. choices: present;absent. Specifies if address need to be added or deleted.
name: ${2:undefined} # required. Name of the address to add or delete.
type: ${3|iprange,fqdn,ipmask,geography|} # not required. choices: iprange;fqdn;ipmask;geography. Type of the address.
interface: ${4:any} # not required. interface name the address apply to.
backup_filename: ${5:undefined} # not required. Specifies the backup filename. If omitted filename will be formatted like HOST_config.YYYY-MM-DD@HH:MM:SS
host: ${6:undefined} # not required. Specifies the DNS hostname or IP address for connecting to the remote fortios device. Required when I(file_mode) is False.
country: ${7:undefined} # not required. 2 letter country code (like FR).

value: ${8:undefined} # not required. Address value, based on type. If type=fqdn, somthing like www.google.com. If type=ipmask, you can use simple ip (192.168.0.1), ip+mask (192.168.0.1 255.255.255.0) or CIDR (192.168.0.1/32).
config_file: ${9:undefined} # not required. Path to configuration file. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
vdom: ${10:undefined} # not required. Specifies on which vdom to apply configuration
password: ${11:undefined} # not required. Specifies the password used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.

backup: ${12|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. This argument will cause the module to create a backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the i(backup) folder.
start_ip: ${13:undefined} # not required. First ip in range (used only with type=iprange).
comment: ${14:undefined} # not required. free text to describe address.
backup_path: ${15:undefined} # not required. Specifies where to store backup files. Required if I(backup=yes).
end_ip: ${16:undefined} # not required. Last ip in range (used only with type=iprange).
file_mode: ${17:false} # not required. Don't connect to any device, only use I(config_file) as input and Output.
timeout: ${18:60} # not required. Timeout in seconds for connecting to the remote device.
username: ${19:undefined} # not required. Configures the username used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.

fortios_config.description: Manage config on Fortinet FortiOS firewall devices
body: fortios_config:
filter: ${1:} # not required. Only for partial backup, you can restrict by giving expected configuration path (ex. firewall address).
backup_filename: ${2:undefined} # not required. Specifies the backup filename. If omitted filename will be formatted like HOST_config.YYYY-MM-DD@HH:MM:SS
password: ${3:undefined} # not required. Specifies the password used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.

backup: ${4|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. This argument will cause the module to create a backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the i(backup) folder.
config_file: ${5:undefined} # not required. Path to configuration file. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
vdom: ${6:undefined} # not required. Specifies on which vdom to apply configuration
file_mode: ${7:false} # not required. Don't connect to any device, only use I(config_file) as input and Output.
src: ${8:undefined} # not required. The I(src) argument provides a path to the configuration template to load into the remote device.
backup_path: ${9:undefined} # not required. Specifies where to store backup files. Required if I(backup=yes).
timeout: ${10:60} # not required. Timeout in seconds for connecting to the remote device.
host: ${11:undefined} # not required. Specifies the DNS hostname or IP address for connecting to the remote fortios device. Required when I(file_mode) is False.
username: ${12:undefined} # not required. Configures the username used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.

fortios_ipv4_policy.description: Manage IPv4 policy objects on Fortinet FortiOS firewall devices
body: fortios_ipv4_policy:

id: ${1:undefined} # required. Policy ID. Warning: policy ID number is different than Policy sequence number. The policy ID is the number assigned at policy creation. The sequence number represents the order in which the Fortigate will evaluate the rule for policy enforcement, and also the order in which rules are listed in the GUI and CLI. These two numbers do not necessarily correlate: this module is based off policy ID. TIP: policy ID can be viewed in the GUI by adding 'ID' to the display columns
file_mode: ${2:false} # not required. Don't connect to any device, only use I(config_file) as input and Output.
nat: ${3|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Enable or disable Nat.
src_addr: ${4:undefined} # not required. Specifies source address (or group) object name(s). Required when I(state=present).
logtraffic: ${5|disable,utm,all|} # not required. choices: disable;utm;all. Logs sessions that matched policy.
service_negate: ${6|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Negate policy service(s) defined in service value.
ips_sensor: ${7:undefined} # not required. Specifies IPS Sensor profile name.
av_profile: ${8:undefined} # not required. Specifies Antivirus profile name.
webfilter_profile: ${9:undefined} # not required. Specifies Webfilter profile name.
dst_intf: ${10:any} # not required. Specifies destination interface name(s).
host: ${11:undefined} # not required. Specifies the DNS hostname or IP address for connecting to the remote fortios device. Required when I(file_mode) is False.
config_file: ${12:undefined} # not required. Path to configuration file. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
timeout: ${13:60} # not required. Timeout in seconds for connecting to the remote device.

backup: ${14|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. This argument will cause the module to create a backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the i(backup) folder.
schedule: ${15:always} # not required. defines policy schedule.
dst_addr: ${16:undefined} # not required. Specifies destination address (or group) object name(s). Required when I(state=present).
password: ${17:undefined} # not required. Specifies the password used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
backup_filename: ${18:undefined} # not required. Specifies the backup filename. If omitted filename will be formatted like HOST_config.YYYY-MM-DD@HH:MM:SS
src_addr_negate: ${19|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Negate source address param.
src_intf: ${20:any} # not required. Specifies source interface name(s).
vdom: ${21:undefined} # not required. Specifies on which vdom to apply configuration
logtraffic_start: ${22|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Logs beginning of session as well.
dst_addr_negate: ${23|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Negate destination address param.
fixedport: ${24|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Use fixed port for nat.
application_list: ${25:undefined} # not required. Specifies Application Control name.
comment: ${26:undefined} # not required. free text to describe policy.
backup_path: ${27:undefined} # not required. Specifies where to store backup files. Required if I(backup=yes).
poolname: ${28:undefined} # not required. Specifies NAT pool name.
state: ${29|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Specifies if policy I(id) need to be added or deleted.
username: ${30:undefined} # not required. Configures the username used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
policy_action: ${31|accept,deny|} # not required. choices: accept;deny. Specifies accept or deny action policy. Required when I(state=present).
service: ${32:undefined} # not required. Specifies policy service(s), could be a list (ex: ['MAIL','DNS']). Required when I(state=present).

gc_storage.description: This module manages objects/buckets in Google Cloud Storage.
body: gc_storage:
gs_secret_key: ${1:null} # required. GS secret key. If not set then the value of the GS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

mode: ${2|get,put,get_url,get_str,delete,create|} # required. choices: get;put;get_url;get_str;delete;create. Switches the module behaviour between upload, download, get_url (return download url) , get_str (download object as string), create (bucket) and delete (bucket).
gs_access_key: ${3:null} # required. GS access key. If not set then the value of the GS_ACCESS_KEY_ID environment variable is used.
bucket: ${4:undefined} # required. Bucket name.
dest: ${5:undefined} # not required. The destination file path when downloading an object/key with a GET operation.
force: ${6:true} # not required. Forces an overwrite either locally on the filesystem or remotely with the object/key. Used with PUT and GET operations.

permission: ${7:private} # not required. This option let's the user set the canned permissions on the object/bucket that are created. The permissions that can be set are 'private', 'public-read', 'authenticated-read'.
region: ${8:US} # not required. The gs region to use. If not defined then the value 'US' will be used. See U(https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/bucket-locations)
src: ${9:null} # not required. The source file path when performing a PUT operation.
object: ${10:null} # not required. Keyname of the object inside the bucket. Can be also be used to create "virtual directories" (see examples).
versioning: ${11|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. Whether versioning is enabled or disabled (note that once versioning is enabled, it can only be suspended)
headers: ${12:{}} # not required. Headers to attach to object.

expiration: ${13:null} # not required. Time limit (in seconds) for the URL generated and returned by GCA when performing a mode=put or mode=get_url operation. This url is only available when public-read is the acl for the object.

gcdns_record.description: Creates or removes resource records in Google Cloud DNS
body: gcdns_record:
type: ${1|A,AAAA,CNAME,SRV,TXT,SOA,NS,MX,SPF,PTR|} # required. choices: A;AAAA;CNAME;SRV;TXT;SOA;NS;MX;SPF;PTR. The type of resource record to add.
record: ${2:undefined} # required. The fully-qualified domain name of the resource record.

record_data: ${3:undefined} # not required. The record_data to use for the resource record.,I(record_data) must be specified if I(state) is C(present) or I(overwrite) is C(True), or the module will fail.,Valid record_data vary based on the record's I(type). In addition, resource records that contain a DNS domain name in the value field (e.g., CNAME, PTR, SRV, .etc) MUST include a trailing dot in the value.,Individual string record_data for TXT records must be enclosed in double quotes.,For resource records that have the same name but different record_data (e.g., multiple A records), they must be defined as multiple list entries in a single record.
ttl: ${4:300} # not required. The amount of time in seconds that a resource record will remain cached by a caching resolver.
project_id: ${5:null} # not required. The Google Cloud Platform project ID to use.
service_account_email: ${6:null} # not required. The e-mail address for a service account with access to Google Cloud DNS.

overwrite: ${7|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Whether an attempt to overwrite an existing record should succeed or fail. The behavior of this option depends on I(state).,If I(state) is C(present) and I(overwrite) is C(True), this module will replace an existing resource record of the same name with the provided I(record_data). If I(state) is C(present) and I(overwrite) is C(False), this module will fail if there is an existing resource record with the same name and type, but different resource data.,If I(state) is C(absent) and I(overwrite) is C(True), this module will remove the given resource record unconditionally. If I(state) is C(absent) and I(overwrite) is C(False), this module will fail if the provided record_data do not match exactly with the existing resource record's record_data.

zone: ${8:undefined} # not required. The DNS domain name of the zone (e.g., example.com).,One of either I(zone) or I(zone_id) must be specified as an option, or the module will fail.,If both I(zone) and I(zone_id) are specified, I(zone_id) will be used.

pem_file: ${9:null} # not required. The path to the PEM file associated with the service account email.,This option is deprecated and may be removed in a future release. Use I(credentials_file) instead.
state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the given resource record should or should not be present.
credentials_file: ${11:null} # not required. The path to the JSON file associated with the service account email.

zone_id: ${12:undefined} # not required. The Google Cloud ID of the zone (e.g., example-com).,One of either I(zone) or I(zone_id) must be specified as an option, or the module will fail.,These usually take the form of domain names with the dots replaced with dashes. A zone ID will never have any dots in it.,I(zone_id) can be faster than I(zone) in projects with a large number of zones.,If both I(zone) and I(zone_id) are specified, I(zone_id) will be used.

gcdns_zone.description: Creates or removes zones in Google Cloud DNS
body: gcdns_zone:

zone: ${1:undefined} # required. The DNS domain name of the zone.,This is NOT the Google Cloud DNS zone ID (e.g., example-com). If you attempt to specify a zone ID, this module will attempt to create a TLD and will fail.
description: ${2:} # not required. An arbitrary text string to use for the zone description.

pem_file: ${3:null} # not required. The path to the PEM file associated with the service account email.,This option is deprecated and may be removed in a future release. Use I(credentials_file) instead.
project_id: ${4:null} # not required. The Google Cloud Platform project ID to use.
state: ${5|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the given zone should or should not be present.
credentials_file: ${6:null} # not required. The path to the JSON file associated with the service account email.
service_account_email: ${7:null} # not required. The e-mail address for a service account with access to Google Cloud DNS.
gce:
zone: ${1:us-central1-a} # required. the GCE zone to use. The list of available zones is at U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/regions-zones/regions-zones#available).
disk_size: ${2:10} # not required. The size of the boot disk created for this instance (in GB)
preemptible: ${3:false} # not required. if set to true, instances will be preemptible and time-limited. (requires libcloud >= 0.20.0)
subnetwork: ${4:null} # not required. name of the subnetwork in which the instance should be created
project_id: ${5:null} # not required. your GCE project ID
image_family: ${6:null} # not required. image family from which to select the image.  The most recent non-deprecated image in the family will be used.
service_account_email: ${7:null} # not required. service account email

disks: ${8:null} # not required. a list of persistent disks to attach to the instance; a string value gives the name of the disk; alternatively, a dictionary value can define 'name' and 'mode' ('READ_ONLY' or 'READ_WRITE'). The first entry will be the boot disk (which must be READ_WRITE).
ip_forward: ${9:false} # not required. set to true if the instance can forward ip packets (useful for gateways)
instance_names: ${10:null} # not required. a comma-separated list of instance names to create or destroy
num_instances: ${11:undefined} # not required. can be used with 'name', specifies the number of nodes to provision using 'name' as a base name
machine_type: ${12:n1-standard-1} # not required. machine type to use for the instance, use 'n1-standard-1' by default
name: ${13:undefined} # not required. either a name of a single instance or when used with 'num_instances', the base name of a cluster of nodes
metadata: ${14:null} # not required. a hash/dictionary of custom data for the instance; '{"key":"value", ...}'

service_account_permissions: ${15|bigquery,cloud-platform,compute-ro,compute-rw,useraccounts-ro,useraccounts-rw,datastore,logging-write,monitoring,sql-admin,storage-full,storage-ro,storage-rw,taskqueue,userinfo-email|} # not required. choices: bigquery;cloud-platform;compute-ro;compute-rw;useraccounts-ro;useraccounts-rw;datastore;logging-write;monitoring;sql-admin;storage-full;storage-ro;storage-rw;taskqueue;userinfo-email. service account permissions (see U(https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/instances/create), --scopes section for detailed information)
credentials_file: ${16:null} # not required. path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
tags: ${17:null} # not required. a comma-separated list of tags to associate with the instance
image: ${18:debian-8} # not required. image string to use for the instance (default will follow latest stable debian image)
disk_auto_delete: ${19:true} # not required. if set boot disk will be removed after instance destruction
external_ip: ${20:ephemeral} # not required. type of external ip, ephemeral by default; alternatively, a fixed gce ip or ip name can be given. Specify 'none' if no external ip is desired.
network: ${21:default} # not required. name of the network, 'default' will be used if not specified
pem_file: ${22:null} # not required. path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
persistent_boot_disk: ${23:false} # not required. if set, create the instance with a persistent boot disk
external_projects: ${24:null} # not required. A list of other projects (accessible with the provisioning credentials) to be searched for the image.
state: ${25|active,present,absent,deleted,started,stopped,terminated|} # not required. choices: active;present;absent;deleted;started;stopped;terminated. desired state of the resource

gce_eip.description: Create or Destroy Global or Regional External IP addresses.
body: gce_eip:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of Address.
region: ${2:undefined} # required. Region to create the address in. Set to 'global' to create a global address.
state: ${3|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. The state the address should be in. C(present) or C(absent) are the only valid options.
gce_img:
name: ${1:null} # required. the name of the image to create or delete
family: ${2:null} # not required. an optional family name
description: ${3:null} # not required. an optional description
project_id: ${4:null} # not required. your GCE project ID
service_account_email: ${5:null} # not required. service account email
zone: ${6:us-central1-a} # not required. the zone of the disk specified by source
pem_file: ${7:null} # not required. path to the pem file associated with the service account email
source: ${8:null} # not required. the source disk or the Google Cloud Storage URI to create the image from
state: ${9|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. desired state of the image
timeout: ${10:180} # not required. timeout for the operation

gce_instance_template.description: create or destroy instance templates of Compute Engine of GCP.
body: gce_instance_template:
name: ${1:null} # required. The name of the GCE instance template.
can_ip_forward: ${2:false} # not required. Set to True to allow instance to send/receive non-matching src/dst packets.
size: ${3:f1-micro} # not required. The desired machine type for the instance template.
tags: ${4:null} # not required. a comma-separated list of tags to associate with the instance
disk_type: ${5:pd-standard} # not required. Specify a C(pd-standard) disk or C(pd-ssd) for an SSD disk.
project_id: ${6:null} # not required. your GCE project ID
image_family: ${7:null} # not required. The image family to use to create the instance. If I(image) has been used I(image_family) is ignored. Cannot specify both I(image) and I(source).
service_account_email: ${8:null} # not required. service account email
nic_gce_struct: ${9:null} # not required. Support passing in the GCE-specific formatted networkInterfaces[] structure.

disks: ${10:null} # not required. a list of persistent disks to attach to the instance; a string value gives the name of the disk; alternatively, a dictionary value can define 'name' and 'mode' ('READ_ONLY' or 'READ_WRITE'). The first entry will be the boot disk (which must be READ_WRITE).
automatic_restart: ${11:null} # not required. Defines whether the instance should be automatically restarted when it is terminated by Compute Engine.
network: ${12:default} # not required. The network to associate with the instance.
metadata: ${13:null} # not required. a hash/dictionary of custom data for the instance; '{"key":"value", ...}'
description: ${14:null} # not required. description of instance template

disks_gce_struct: ${15:null} # not required. Support passing in the GCE-specific formatted formatted disks[] structure. Case sensitive. see U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instanceTemplates#resource) for detailed information

service_account_permissions: ${16|bigquery,cloud-platform,compute-ro,compute-rw,useraccounts-ro,useraccounts-rw,datastore,logging-write,monitoring,sql-admin,storage-full,storage-ro,storage-rw,taskqueue,userinfo-email|} # not required. choices: bigquery;cloud-platform;compute-ro;compute-rw;useraccounts-ro;useraccounts-rw;datastore;logging-write;monitoring;sql-admin;storage-full;storage-ro;storage-rw;taskqueue;userinfo-email. service account permissions (see U(https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/instances/create), --scopes section for detailed information)
credentials_file: ${17:null} # not required. path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
subnetwork: ${18:null} # not required. The Subnetwork resource name for this instance.
image: ${19:null} # not required. The image to use to create the instance. Cannot specify both both I(image) and I(source).
disk_auto_delete: ${20:true} # not required. Indicate that the boot disk should be deleted when the Node is deleted.

external_ip: ${21:ephemeral} # not required. The external IP address to use. If C(ephemeral), a new non-static address will be used.  If C(None), then no external address will be used.  To use an existing static IP address specify address name.
preemptible: ${22:null} # not required. Defines whether the instance is preemptible.
pem_file: ${23:null} # not required. path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
source: ${24:null} # not required. A source disk to attach to the instance. Cannot specify both I(image) and I(source).
state: ${25|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. The desired state for the instance template.
subnetwork_region: ${26:null} # not required. Region that subnetwork resides in. (Required for subnetwork to successfully complete)

gce_labels.description: Create, Update or Destroy GCE Labels.
body: gce_labels:
resource_location: ${1:undefined} # not required. The location of resource (global, us-central1-f, etc.)
resource_name: ${2:undefined} # not required. The name of resource.
resource_type: ${3:undefined} # not required. The type of resource (instances, disks, snapshots, images)
labels: ${4:undefined} # not required. A list of labels (key/value pairs) to add or remove for the resource.
resource_url: ${5:undefined} # not required. The 'self_link' for the resource (instance, disk, snapshot, etc)
gce_lb:
port_range: ${1:null} # not required. the port (range) to forward, e.g. 80 or 8000-8888 defaults to all ports
project_id: ${2:null} # not required. your GCE project ID
httphealthcheck_healthy_count: ${3:2} # not required. number of consecutive successful checks before marking a node healthy
service_account_email: ${4:null} # not required. service account email
httphealthcheck_unhealthy_count: ${5:2} # not required. number of consecutive failed checks before marking a node unhealthy
httphealthcheck_name: ${6:null} # not required. the name identifier for the HTTP health check
credentials_file: ${7:null} # not required. path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
name: ${8:null} # not required. name of the load-balancer resource
state: ${9|active,present,absent,deleted|} # not required. choices: active;present;absent;deleted. desired state of the LB
httphealthcheck_host: ${10:null} # not required. host header to pass through on HTTP check requests
protocol: ${11|tcp,udp|} # not required. choices: tcp;udp. the protocol used for the load-balancer packet forwarding, tcp or udp
httphealthcheck_interval: ${12:5} # not required. the duration in seconds between each health check request
httphealthcheck_path: ${13:/} # not required. the url path to use for HTTP health checking
region: ${14:undefined} # not required. the GCE region where the load-balancer is defined
httphealthcheck_port: ${15:80} # not required. the TCP port to use for HTTP health checking
external_ip: ${16:null} # not required. the external static IPv4 (or auto-assigned) address for the LB
pem_file: ${17:null} # not required. path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
members: ${18:undefined} # not required. a list of zone/nodename pairs, e.g ['us-central1-a/www-a', ...]
httphealthcheck_timeout: ${19:5} # not required. the timeout in seconds before a request is considered a failed check

gce_mig.description: Create, Update or Destroy a Managed Instance Group (MIG).
body: gce_mig:
zone: ${1:undefined} # required. The GCE zone to use for this Managed Instance Group.
name: ${2:undefined} # required. Name of the Managed Instance Group.
size: ${3:undefined} # not required. Size of Managed Instance Group.  If MIG already exists, it will be resized to the number provided here.  Required for creating MIGs.
state: ${4|absent,present|} # not required. choices: absent;present. desired state of the resource

template: ${5:undefined} # not required. Instance Template to be used in creating the VMs.  See U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-templates) to learn more about Instance Templates.  Required for creating MIGs.
project_id: ${6:null} # not required. GCE project ID

autoscaling: ${7:null} # not required. A dictionary of configuration for the autoscaler. 'enabled (bool)', 'name (str)' and policy.max_instances (int) are required fields if autoscaling is used. See U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/beta/autoscalers) for more information on Autoscaling.
service_account_email: ${8:null} # not required. service account email
named_ports: ${9:null} # not required. Define named ports that backend services can forward data to.  Format is a a list of name:port dictionaries.
credentials_file: ${10:null} # not required. Path to the JSON file associated with the service account email

gce_net.description: create/destroy GCE networks and firewall rules
body: gce_net:
src_range: ${1:} # not required. the source IPv4 address range in CIDR notation

ipv4_range: ${2:undefined} # not required. the IPv4 address range in CIDR notation for the network this parameter is not mandatory when you specified existing network in name parameter, but when you create new network, this parameter is mandatory
project_id: ${3:null} # not required. your GCE project ID
service_account_email: ${4:null} # not required. service account email
fwname: ${5:null} # not required. name of the firewall rule
allowed: ${6:null} # not required. the protocol:ports to allow ('tcp:80' or 'tcp:80,443' or 'tcp:80-800;udp:1-25') this parameter is mandatory when creating or updating a firewall rule
credentials_file: ${7:null} # not required. path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
target_tags: ${8:} # not required. the target instance tags for creating a firewall rule
name: ${9:null} # not required. name of the network
subnet_name: ${10:null} # not required. name of subnet to create
subnet_region: ${11:null} # not required. region of subnet to create
src_tags: ${12:} # not required. the source instance tags for creating a firewall rule
subnet_desc: ${13:null} # not required. description of subnet to create

mode: ${14|legacy,auto,custom|} # not required. choices: legacy;auto;custom. network mode for Google Cloud "legacy" indicates a network with an IP address range "auto" automatically generates subnetworks in different regions "custom" uses networks to group subnets of user specified IP address ranges https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/networking#network_types
pem_file: ${15:null} # not required. path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
state: ${16|active,present,absent,deleted|} # not required. choices: active;present;absent;deleted. desired state of the network or firewall
gce_pd:
name: ${1:null} # required. name of the disk
instance_name: ${2:null} # not required. instance name if you wish to attach or detach the disk
state: ${3|active,present,absent,deleted|} # not required. choices: active;present;absent;deleted. desired state of the persistent disk
disk_type: ${4|pd-standard,pd-ssd|} # not required. choices: pd-standard;pd-ssd. type of disk provisioned
detach_only: ${5|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. do not destroy the disk, merely detach it from an instance
project_id: ${6:null} # not required. your GCE project ID
delete_on_termination: ${7|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. If yes, deletes the volume when instance is terminated
service_account_email: ${8:null} # not required. service account email
image: ${9:null} # not required. the source image to use for the disk
snapshot: ${10:null} # not required. the source snapshot to use for the disk
mode: ${11|READ_WRITE,READ_ONLY|} # not required. choices: READ_WRITE;READ_ONLY. GCE mount mode of disk, READ_ONLY (default) or READ_WRITE
zone: ${12:us-central1-b} # not required. zone in which to create the disk
pem_file: ${13:null} # not required. path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
size_gb: ${14:10} # not required. whole integer size of disk (in GB) to create, default is 10 GB
credentials_file: ${15:null} # not required. path to the JSON file associated with the service account email

gce_snapshot.description: Create or destroy snapshots for GCE storage volumes
body: gce_snapshot:
instance_name: ${1:undefined} # required. The GCE instance to snapshot
project_id: ${2:undefined} # required. The GCP project ID to use
credentials_file: ${3:undefined} # required. The path to the credentials file associated with the service account
service_account_email: ${4:undefined} # required. GCP service account email for the project where the instance resides
snapshot_name: ${5:undefined} # not required. The name of the snapshot to manage
disks: ${6:all} # not required. A list of disks to create snapshots for. If none is provided, all of the volumes will be snapshotted
state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether a snapshot should be C(present) or C(absent)

gce_tag.description: add or remove tag(s) to/from GCE instances
body: gce_tag:
tags: ${1:undefined} # required. Comma-separated list of tags to add or remove.
instance_name: ${2:undefined} # not required. The name of the GCE instance to add/remove tags.,Required if C(instance_pattern) is not specified.
project_id: ${3:undefined} # not required. Your GCE project ID.
service_account_email: ${4:undefined} # not required. Service account email.

instance_pattern: ${5:undefined} # not required. The pattern of GCE instance names to match for adding/removing tags.  Full-Python regex is supported. See U(https://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html) for details.,If C(instance_name) is not specified, this field is required.
zone: ${6:us-central1-a} # not required. The zone of the disk specified by source.
pem_file: ${7:undefined} # not required. Path to the PEM file associated with the service account email.
state: ${8|absent,present|} # not required. choices: absent;present. Desired state of the tags.
gconftool2:
state: ${1|absent,get,present|} # required. choices: absent;get;present. The action to take upon the key/value.
key: ${2:undefined} # required. A GConf preference key is an element in the GConf repository that corresponds to an application preference. See man gconftool-2(1)

value: ${3:undefined} # not required. Preference keys typically have simple values such as strings, integers, or lists of strings and integers. This is ignored if the state is "get". See man gconftool-2(1)
direct: ${4:no} # not required. Access the config database directly, bypassing server.  If direct is specified then the config_source must be specified as well. See man gconftool-2(1)
config_source: ${5:undefined} # not required. Specify a configuration source to use rather than the default path. See man gconftool-2(1)
value_type: ${6|bool,float,int,string|} # not required. choices: bool;float;int;string. The type of value being set. This is ignored if the state is "get".

gcp_backend_service.description: Create or Destroy a Backend Service.
body: gcp_backend_service:

backends: ${1:undefined} # required. List of backends that make up the backend service. A backend is made up of an instance group and optionally several other parameters.  See U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/backendServices) for details.
backend_service_name: ${2:undefined} # required. Name of the Backend Service.
healthchecks: ${3:undefined} # required. List of healthchecks. Only one healthcheck is supported.
protocol: ${4:undefined} # not required. The protocol this Backend Service uses to communicate with backends. Possible values are HTTP, HTTPS, TCP, and SSL. The default is HTTP.
port_name: ${5:null} # not required. Name of the port on the managed instance group (MIG) that backend services can forward data to. Required for external load balancing.
project_id: ${6:null} # not required. GCE project ID.
enable_cdn: ${7:undefined} # not required. If true, enable Cloud CDN for this Backend Service.
service_account_email: ${8:null} # not required. Service account email
timeout: ${9:undefined} # not required. How many seconds to wait for the backend before considering it a failed request. Default is 30 seconds. Valid range is 1-86400.
state: ${10|absent,present|} # not required. choices: absent;present. Desired state of the resource
credentials_file: ${11:null} # not required. Path to the JSON file associated with the service account email.
gcp_dns_managed_zone:
scopes: ${1:undefined} # required. Array of scopes to be used.
auth_kind: ${2|machineaccount,serviceaccount,application|} # required. choices: machineaccount;serviceaccount;application. The type of credential used.
state: ${3|present,absent|} # required. choices: present;absent. Whether the given object should exist in GCP
name: ${4:undefined} # required. User assigned name for this resource. Must be unique within the project.
description: ${5:undefined} # not required. A mutable string of at most 1024 characters associated with this resource for the user's convenience. Has no effect on the managed zone's function.

name_server_set: ${6:undefined} # not required. Optionally specifies the NameServerSet for this ManagedZone. A NameServerSet is a set of DNS name servers that all host the same ManagedZones. Most users will leave this field unset.
project: ${7:null} # not required. The Google Cloud Platform project to use.
service_account_file: ${8:undefined} # not required. The path of a Service Account JSON file if serviceaccount is selected as type.
service_account_email: ${9:undefined} # not required. An optional service account email address if machineaccount is selected and the user does not wish to use the default email.
dns_name: ${10:undefined} # not required. The DNS name of this managed zone, for instance "example.com.".

gcp_forwarding_rule.description: Create, Update or Destroy a Forwarding_Rule.
body: gcp_forwarding_rule:
state: ${1|present,absent|} # required. choices: present;absent. The state of the Forwarding Rule. 'present' or 'absent'
forwarding_rule_name: ${2:undefined} # required. Name of the Forwarding_Rule.

target: ${3:undefined} # not required. Target resource for forwarding rule. For global proxy, this is a Global TargetProxy resource. Required for external load balancing (including Global load balancing)
