datacenter: ${4:undefined} # not required. ID of the datacenter where the IP will be created (only for unassigned IPs).
type: ${5|IPV4,IPV6|} # not required. choices: IPV4;IPV6. Type of IP. Currently, only IPV4 is available.
api_url: ${6:undefined} # not required. Custom API URL. Overrides the ONEANDONE_API_URL environement variable.
reverse_dns: ${7:undefined} # not required. Reverse DNS name. maxLength=256
wait_timeout: ${8:600} # not required. how long before wait gives up, in seconds
wait: ${9|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. wait for the instance to be in state 'running' before returning
state: ${10|present,absent,update|} # not required. choices: present;absent;update. Define a public ip state to create, remove, or update.

oneandone_server.description: Create, destroy, start, stop, and reboot a 1&1 Host server.
body: oneandone_server:
auth_token: ${1:undefined} # required. Authenticating API token provided by 1&1. Overrides the ONEANDONE_AUTH_TOKEN environement variable.

fixed_instance_size: ${2|S,M,L,XL,XXL,3XL,4XL,5XL|} # required. choices: S;M;L;XL;XXL;3XL;4XL;5XL. The instance size name or ID of the server. It is required only for 'present' state, and it is mutually exclusive with vcore, cores_per_processor, ram, and hdds parameters.
cores_per_processor: ${3:undefined} # not required. The number of cores per processor. It must be provided with vcore, ram, and hdds parameters.
datacenter: ${4|US,ES,DE,GB|} # not required. choices: US;ES;DE;GB. The datacenter location.
count: ${5:1} # not required. The number of servers to create.
ram: ${6:undefined} # not required. The amount of RAM memory. It must be provided with with vcore, cores_per_processor, and hdds parameters.
api_url: ${7:undefined} # not required. Custom API URL. Overrides the ONEANDONE_API_URL environement variable.

wait: ${8|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. Wait for the server to be in state 'running' before returning. Also used for delete operation (set to 'false' if you don't want to wait for each individual server to be deleted before moving on with other tasks.)
appliance: ${9:undefined} # not required. The operating system name or ID for the server. It is required only for 'present' state.
private_network: ${10:undefined} # not required. The private network name or ID.
wait_timeout: ${11:600} # not required. how long before wait gives up, in seconds
hdds: ${12:undefined} # not required. A list of hard disks with nested "size" and "is_main" properties. It must be provided with vcore, cores_per_processor, and ram parameters.
server_type: ${13|cloud,baremetal,k8s_node|} # not required. choices: cloud;baremetal;k8s_node. The type of server to be built.
monitoring_policy: ${14:undefined} # not required. The monitoring policy name or ID.
vcore: ${15:undefined} # not required. The total number of processors. It must be provided with cores_per_processor, ram, and hdds parameters.
server: ${16:undefined} # not required. Server identifier (ID or hostname). It is required for all states except 'running' and 'present'.
description: ${17:undefined} # not required. The description of the server.
firewall_policy: ${18:undefined} # not required. The firewall policy name or ID.
wait_interval: ${19:5} # not required. Defines the number of seconds to wait when using the wait_for methods
ssh_key: ${20:None} # not required. User's public SSH key (contents, not path).
state: ${21|present,absent,running,stopped|} # not required. choices: present;absent;running;stopped. Define a server's state to create, remove, start or stop it.
load_balancer: ${22:undefined} # not required. The load balancer name or ID.

auto_increment: ${23|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. When creating multiple servers at once, whether to differentiate hostnames by appending a count after them or substituting the count where there is a %02d or %03d in the hostname string.
hostname: ${24:undefined} # not required. The hostname or ID of the server. Only used when state is 'present'.

onyx_bgp.description: Configures BGP on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_bgp:
as_number: ${1:undefined} # required. Local AS number.
neighbors: ${2:undefined} # not required. List of neighbors. Required if I(state=present).
state: ${3|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. BGP state.
router_id: ${4:undefined} # not required. Router IP address. Required if I(state=present).
networks: ${5:undefined} # not required. List of advertised networks.

onyx_command.description: Run commands on remote devices running Mellanox ONYX
body: onyx_command:

commands: ${1:undefined} # required. List of commands to send to the remote Mellanox ONYX network device. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retries has expired.

match: ${2|any,all|} # not required. choices: any;all. The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.

retries: ${3:10} # not required. Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

wait_for: ${4:undefined} # not required. List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

interval: ${5:1} # not required. Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.
provider: ${6:null} # not required. A dict object containing connection details.
onyx_config:

save: ${1|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running- config to the startup-config at the conclusion of the module running.  If check mode is specified, this argument is ignored.

backup: ${2|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.
provider: ${3:null} # not required. A dict object containing connection details.

replace: ${4|line,block|} # not required. choices: line;block. Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct

src: ${5:undefined} # not required. Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines), I(parents).

match: ${6|line,strict,exact,none|} # not required. choices: line;strict;exact;none. Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

after: ${7:undefined} # not required. The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

config: ${8:undefined} # not required. The C(config) argument allows the playbook designer to supply the base configuration to be used to validate configuration changes necessary.  If this argument is provided, the module will not download the running-config from the remote node.

before: ${9:undefined} # not required. The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

lines: ${10:undefined} # not required. The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

parents: ${11:undefined} # not required. The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

onyx_facts.description: Collect facts from Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_facts:

gather_subset: ${1:version} # not required. When supplied, this argument will restrict the facts collected to a given subset.  Possible values for this argument include all, version, module, and interfaces.  Can specify a list of values to include a larger subset.  Values can also be used with an initial C(M(!)) to specify that a specific subset should not be collected.

onyx_interface.description: Manage Interfaces on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_interface:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the Interface.
description: ${2:undefined} # not required. Description of Interface.

tx_rate: ${3:undefined} # not required. Transmit rate in bits per second (bps).,This is state check parameter only.,Supports conditionals, see L(Conditionals in Networking Modules,../network/user_guide/network_working_with_command_output.html)

delay: ${4:10} # not required. Time in seconds to wait before checking for the operational state on remote device. This wait is applicable for operational state argument which are I(state) with values C(up)/C(down).
mtu: ${5:undefined} # not required. Maximum size of transmit packet.
duplex: ${6|full,half,auto|} # not required. choices: full;half;auto. Interface link status
enabled: ${7:undefined} # not required. Interface link status.
speed: ${8|1G,10G,25G,40G,50G,56G,100G|} # not required. choices: 1G;10G;25G;40G;50G;56G;100G. Interface link speed.

rx_rate: ${9:undefined} # not required. Receiver rate in bits per second (bps).,This is state check parameter only.,Supports conditionals, see L(Conditionals in Networking Modules,../network/user_guide/network_working_with_command_output.html)

state: ${10|present,absent,up,down|} # not required. choices: present;absent;up;down. State of the Interface configuration, C(up) means present and operationally up and C(down) means present and operationally C(down)
aggregate: ${11:undefined} # not required. List of Interfaces definitions.
purge: ${12:false} # not required. Purge Interfaces not defined in the aggregate parameter. This applies only for logical interface.

onyx_l2_interface.description: Manage Layer-2 interface on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_l2_interface:
mode: ${1|access,trunk,hybrid|} # not required. choices: access;trunk;hybrid. Mode in which interface needs to be configured.
access_vlan: ${2:undefined} # not required. Configure given VLAN in access port.
trunk_allowed_vlans: ${3:undefined} # not required. List of allowed VLANs in a given trunk port.
state: ${4|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the Layer-2 Interface configuration.
aggregate: ${5:undefined} # not required. List of Layer-2 interface definitions.
name: ${6:undefined} # not required. Name of the interface.

onyx_l3_interface.description: Manage L3 interfaces on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_l3_interface:
ipv4: ${1:undefined} # not required. IPv4 of the L3 interface.
purge: ${2:false} # not required. Purge L3 interfaces not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
ipv6: ${3:undefined} # not required. IPv6 of the L3 interface (not supported for now).
state: ${4|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the L3 interface configuration.
aggregate: ${5:undefined} # not required. List of L3 interfaces definitions
name: ${6:undefined} # not required. Name of the L3 interface.

onyx_linkagg.description: Manage link aggregation groups on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_linkagg:
members: ${1:undefined} # required. List of members interfaces of the link aggregation group. The value can be single interface or list of interfaces.
name: ${2:undefined} # required. Name of the link aggregation group.

mode: ${3|on,active,passive|} # not required. choices: on;active;passive. Mode of the link aggregation group. A value of C(on) will enable LACP. C(active) configures the link to actively information about the state of the link, or it can be configured in C(passive) mode ie. send link state information only when received them from another link.
state: ${4|present,absent,up,down|} # not required. choices: present;absent;up;down. State of the link aggregation group.
purge: ${5:false} # not required. Purge link aggregation groups not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
aggregate: ${6:undefined} # not required. List of link aggregation definitions.

onyx_lldp.description: Manage LLDP configuration on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_lldp:
state: ${1|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the LLDP protocol configuration.

onyx_lldp_interface.description: Manage LLDP interfaces configuration on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_lldp_interface:
state: ${1|present,absent,enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: present;absent;enabled;disabled. State of the LLDP configuration.
aggregate: ${2:undefined} # not required. List of interfaces LLDP should be configured on.
name: ${3:undefined} # not required. Name of the interface LLDP should be configured on.
purge: ${4:false} # not required. Purge interfaces not defined in the aggregate parameter.

onyx_magp.description: Manage MAGP protocol on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_magp:
interface: ${1:undefined} # required. VLAN Interface name.
magp_id: ${2:undefined} # required. MAGP instance number 1-255
state: ${3|present,absent,enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: present;absent;enabled;disabled. MAGP state.
router_ip: ${4:undefined} # not required. MAGP router IP address.
router_mac: ${5:undefined} # not required. MAGP router MAC address.

onyx_mlag_ipl.description: Manage IPL (inter-peer link) on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_mlag_ipl:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the interface (port-channel) IPL should be configured on.
peer_address: ${2:undefined} # not required. IPL peer IP address.
state: ${3|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. IPL state.
vlan_interface: ${4:undefined} # not required. Name of the IPL vlan interface.

onyx_mlag_vip.description: Configures MLAG VIP on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_mlag_vip:
ipaddress: ${1:undefined} # not required. Virtual IP address of the MLAG. Required if I(state=present).
mac_address: ${2:undefined} # not required. MLAG system MAC address. Required if I(state=present).
state: ${3|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. MLAG VIP state.
group_name: ${4:undefined} # not required. MLAG group name. Required if I(state=present).
delay: ${5:12} # not required. Delay interval, in seconds, waiting for the changes on mlag VIP to take effect.

onyx_ospf.description: Manage OSPF protocol on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_ospf:
ospf: ${1:undefined} # required. OSPF instance number 1-65535
interfaces: ${2:undefined} # not required. List of interfaces and areas. Required if I(state=present).
state: ${3|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. OSPF state.
router_id: ${4:undefined} # not required. OSPF router ID. Required if I(state=present).

onyx_pfc_interface.description: Manage priority flow control on ONYX network devices
body: onyx_pfc_interface:
state: ${1|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. State of the PFC configuration.
aggregate: ${2:undefined} # not required. List of interfaces PFC should be configured on.
name: ${3:undefined} # not required. Name of the interface PFC should be configured on.
purge: ${4:false} # not required. Purge interfaces not defined in the aggregate parameter.

onyx_protocol.description: Enables/Disables protocols on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_protocol:
lldp: ${1|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. LLDP protocol
lacp: ${2|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. LACP protocol
magp: ${3|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. MAGP protocol
dcb_pfc: ${4|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. DCB priority flow control
ospf: ${5|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. OSPF protocol
ip_l3: ${6|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. IP L3 support
bgp: ${7|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. BGP protocol
igmp_snooping: ${8|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. IP IGMP snooping
ip_routing: ${9|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. IP routing support
mlag: ${10|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. MLAG protocol
spanning_tree: ${11|enabled,disabled|} # not required. choices: enabled;disabled. Spanning Tree support

onyx_vlan.description: Manage VLANs on Mellanox ONYX network devices
body: onyx_vlan:
name: ${1:undefined} # not required. Name of the VLAN.
state: ${2|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. State of the VLAN configuration.
vlan_id: ${3:undefined} # not required. ID of the VLAN.
purge: ${4:false} # not required. Purge VLANs not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
aggregate: ${5:undefined} # not required. List of VLANs definitions.
open_iscsi:
portal: ${1:undefined} # not required. the ip address of the iscsi target
node_user: ${2:undefined} # not required. discovery.sendtargets.auth.username

discover: ${3|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. whether the list of target nodes on the portal should be (re)discovered and added to the persistent iscsi database. Keep in mind that iscsiadm discovery resets configurtion, like node.startup to manual, hence combined with auto_node_startup=yes will always return a changed state.
port: ${4:3260} # not required. the port on which the iscsi target process listens
node_pass: ${5:undefined} # not required. discovery.sendtargets.auth.password
target: ${6:undefined} # not required. the iscsi target name
show_nodes: ${7|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. whether the list of nodes in the persistent iscsi database should be returned by the module
login: ${8|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. whether the target node should be connected
auto_node_startup: ${9|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. whether the target node should be automatically connected at startup
node_auth: ${10:CHAP} # not required. discovery.sendtargets.auth.authmethod
openbsd_pkg:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. A name or a list of names of the packages.
ports_dir: ${2:/usr/ports} # not required. When used in combination with the C(build) option, allows overriding the default ports source directory.
quick: ${3:no} # not required. Replace or delete packages quickly; do not bother with checksums before removing normal files.

state: ${4|absent,latest,present|} # not required. choices: absent;latest;present. C(present) will make sure the package is installed. C(latest) will make sure the latest version of the package is installed. C(absent) will make sure the specified package is not installed.

build: ${5:no} # not required. Build the package from source instead of downloading and installing a binary. Requires that the port source tree is already installed. Automatically builds and installs the 'sqlports' package, if it is not already installed.
clean: ${6:no} # not required. When updating or removing packages, delete the extra configuration file(s) in the old packages which are annotated with @extra in the packaging-list.

opendj_backendprop.description: Will update the backend configuration of OpenDJ via the dsconfig set-backend-prop command.
body: opendj_backendprop:
value: ${1:undefined} # required. The value for the configuration item.
port: ${2:undefined} # required. The Admin port on which the OpenDJ instance is available.
backend: ${3:undefined} # required. The name of the backend on which the property needs to be updated.
name: ${4:undefined} # required. The configuration setting to update.
hostname: ${5:undefined} # required. The hostname of the OpenDJ server.
password: ${6:undefined} # not required. The password for the cn=Directory Manager user.,Either password or passwordfile is needed.
opendj_bindir: ${7:/opt/opendj/bin} # not required. The path to the bin directory of OpenDJ.
passwordfile: ${8:undefined} # not required. Location to the password file which holds the password for the cn=Directory Manager user.,Either password or passwordfile is needed.
state: ${9:present} # not required. If configuration needs to be added/updated
username: ${10:cn=Directory Manager} # not required. The username to connect to.
openshift_raw:

kind: ${1:undefined} # not required. Use to specify an object model. Use to create, delete, or discover an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(api_version), I(name), and I(namespace) to identify a specific object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(kind) from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.
host: ${2:undefined} # not required. Provide a URL for accessing the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_HOST environment variable.
force: ${3:false} # not required. If set to C(True), and I(state) is C(present), an existing object will be replaced.
description: ${4:undefined} # not required. Use only when creating a project, otherwise ignored. Adds a description to the project metadata.
api_key: ${5:undefined} # not required. Token used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_API_KEY environment variable.
password: ${6:undefined} # not required. Provide a password for authenticating with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_PASSWORD environment variable.
verify_ssl: ${7:undefined} # not required. Whether or not to verify the API server's SSL certificates. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_VERIFY_SSL environment variable.
ssl_ca_cert: ${8:undefined} # not required. Path to a CA certificate used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_SSL_CA_CERT environment variable.

kubeconfig: ${9:undefined} # not required. Path to an existing Kubernetes config file. If not provided, and no other connection options are provided, the openshift client will attempt to load the default configuration file from I(~/.kube/config.json). Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_KUBECONFIG environment variable.

api_version: ${10:v1} # not required. Use to specify the API version. Use to create, delete, or discover an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(kind), I(name), and I(namespace) to identify a specific object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(apiVersion) from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.
display_name: ${11:undefined} # not required. Use only when creating a project, otherwise ignored. Adds a display name to the project metadata.

src: ${12:undefined} # not required. Provide a path to a file containing a valid YAML definition of an object to be created or updated. Mutually exclusive with I(resource_definition). NOTE: I(kind), I(api_version), I(name), and I(namespace) will be overwritten by corresponding values found in the configuration read in from the I(src) file.,Reads from the local file system. To read from the Ansible controller's file system, use the file lookup plugin or template lookup plugin, combined with the from_yaml filter, and pass the result to I(resource_definition). See Examples below.
cert_file: ${13:undefined} # not required. Path to a certificate used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_CERT_FILE environment variable.
key_file: ${14:undefined} # not required. Path to a key file used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_HOST environment variable.
context: ${15:undefined} # not required. The name of a context found in the config file. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_CONTEXT environment variable.

namespace: ${16:undefined} # not required. Use to specify an object namespace. Useful when creating, deleting, or discovering an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(api_version), I(kind), and I(name) to identify a specfic object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(metadata.namespace) value from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.

state: ${17|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Determines if an object should be created, patched, or deleted. When set to C(present), an object will be created, if it does not already exist. If set to C(absent), an existing object will be deleted. If set to C(present), an existing object will be patched, if its attributes differ from those specified using I(resource_definition) or I(src).
username: ${18:undefined} # not required. Provide a username for authenticating with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_USERNAME environment variable.

resource_definition: ${19:undefined} # not required. Provide a valid YAML definition for an object when creating or updating. NOTE: I(kind), I(api_version), I(name), and I(namespace) will be overwritten by corresponding values found in the provided I(resource_definition).

name: ${20:undefined} # not required. Use to specify an object name. Use to create, delete, or discover an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(api_version), I(kind) and I(namespace) to identify a specific object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(metadata.name) value from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.

openshift_scale.description: Set a new size for a Deployment Config, Deployment, Replica Set, Replication Controller, or Job.
body: openshift_scale:

current_replicas: ${1:undefined} # not required. For Deployment, ReplicaSet, Replication Controller, only scale, if the number of existing replicas matches. In the case of a Job, update parallelism only if the current parallelism value matches.

wait_timeout: ${2:20} # not required. When C(wait) is I(True), the number of seconds to wait for the I(ready_replicas) status to equal  I(replicas). If the status is not reached within the allotted time, an error will result. In the case of a Job, this option is ignored.

kubeconfig: ${3:undefined} # not required. Path to an existing Kubernetes config file. If not provided, and no other connection options are provided, the openshift client will attempt to load the default configuration file from I(~/.kube/config.json). Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_KUBECONFIG environment variable.
api_key: ${4:undefined} # not required. Token used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_API_KEY environment variable.

resource_definition: ${5:undefined} # not required. Provide a valid YAML definition for an object when creating or updating. NOTE: I(kind), I(api_version), I(name), and I(namespace) will be overwritten by corresponding values found in the provided I(resource_definition).

wait: ${6:true} # not required. For Deployment, ReplicaSet, Replication Controller, wait for the status value of I(ready_replicas) to change to the number of I(replicas). In the case of a Job, this option is ignored.
password: ${7:undefined} # not required. Provide a password for authenticating with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_PASSWORD environment variable.
verify_ssl: ${8:undefined} # not required. Whether or not to verify the API server's SSL certificates. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_VERIFY_SSL environment variable.
resource_version: ${9:undefined} # not required. Only attempt to scale, if the current object version matches.
context: ${10:undefined} # not required. The name of a context found in the config file. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_CONTEXT environment variable.

api_version: ${11:v1} # not required. Use to specify the API version. Use to create, delete, or discover an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(kind), I(name), and I(namespace) to identify a specific object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(apiVersion) from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.
ssl_ca_cert: ${12:undefined} # not required. Path to a CA certificate used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_SSL_CA_CERT environment variable.

src: ${13:undefined} # not required. Provide a path to a file containing a valid YAML definition of an object to be created or updated. Mutually exclusive with I(resource_definition). NOTE: I(kind), I(api_version), I(name), and I(namespace) will be overwritten by corresponding values found in the configuration read in from the I(src) file.,Reads from the local file system. To read from the Ansible controller's file system, use the file lookup plugin or template lookup plugin, combined with the from_yaml filter, and pass the result to I(resource_definition). See Examples below.
replicas: ${14:undefined} # not required. The desired number of replicas.
cert_file: ${15:undefined} # not required. Path to a certificate used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_CERT_FILE environment variable.
key_file: ${16:undefined} # not required. Path to a key file used to authenticate with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_HOST environment variable.

namespace: ${17:undefined} # not required. Use to specify an object namespace. Useful when creating, deleting, or discovering an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(api_version), I(kind), and I(name) to identify a specfic object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(metadata.namespace) value from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.
host: ${18:undefined} # not required. Provide a URL for accessing the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_HOST environment variable.
username: ${19:undefined} # not required. Provide a username for authenticating with the API. Can also be specified via K8S_AUTH_USERNAME environment variable.

kind: ${20:undefined} # not required. Use to specify an object model. Use to create, delete, or discover an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(api_version), I(name), and I(namespace) to identify a specific object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(kind) from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.

name: ${21:undefined} # not required. Use to specify an object name. Use to create, delete, or discover an object without providing a full resource definition. Use in conjunction with I(api_version), I(kind) and I(namespace) to identify a specific object. If I(resource definition) is provided, the I(metadata.name) value from the I(resource_definition) will override this option.
openssl_certificate:

provider: ${1|selfsigned,assertonly,acme|} # required. choices: selfsigned;assertonly;acme. Name of the provider to use to generate/retrieve the OpenSSL certificate. The C(assertonly) provider will not generate files and fail if the certificate file is missing.
path: ${2:undefined} # required. Remote absolute path where the generated certificate file should be created or is already located.
selevel: ${3:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

unsafe_writes: ${4:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.

subject: ${5:undefined} # not required. Key/value pairs that must be present in the subject name field of the certificate. If you need to specify more than one value with the same key, use a list as value.
version: ${6:undefined} # not required. Version of the certificate. Nowadays it should almost always be 3.
owner: ${7:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
not_before: ${8:undefined} # not required. The certificate must start to become valid at this point in time. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME.
valid_at: ${9:undefined} # not required. The certificate must be valid at this point in time. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME.
has_expired: ${10:false} # not required. Checks if the certificate is expired/not expired at the time the module is executed.
privatekey_path: ${11:undefined} # not required. Path to the private key to use when signing the certificate.
acme_accountkey_path: ${12:undefined} # not required. Path to the accountkey for the C(acme) provider
acme_challenge_path: ${13:undefined} # not required. Path to the ACME challenge directory that is served on U(http://<HOST>:80/.well-known/acme-challenge/)
extended_key_usage_strict: ${14:false} # not required. If set to True, the I(extended_key_usage) extension field must contain only these values.
key_usage_strict: ${15:false} # not required. If set to True, the I(key_usage) extension field must contain only these values.
selfsigned_digest: ${16:sha256} # not required. Digest algorithm to be used when self-signing the certificate
setype: ${17:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
subject_alt_name: ${18:undefined} # not required. The I(subject_alt_name) extension field must contain these values.

attributes: ${19:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
invalid_at: ${20:undefined} # not required. The certificate must be invalid at this point in time. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME.
state: ${21|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the certificate should exist or not, taking action if the state is different from what is stated.

selfsigned_not_after: ${22:undefined} # not required. The timestamp at which the certificate stops being valid. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME. If this value is not specified, certificate will stop being valid 10 years from now.
key_usage: ${23:undefined} # not required. The I(key_usage) extension field must contain all these values.
seuser: ${24:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.

mode: ${25:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
valid_in: ${26:undefined} # not required. The certificate must still be valid in I(valid_in) seconds from now.
not_after: ${27:undefined} # not required. The certificate must expire at this point in time. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME.
extended_key_usage: ${28:undefined} # not required. The I(extended_key_usage) extension field must contain all these values.

selfsigned_not_before: ${29:undefined} # not required. The timestamp at which the certificate starts being valid. The timestamp is formatted as an ASN.1 TIME. If this value is not specified, certificate will start being valid from now.
group: ${30:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
signature_algorithms: ${31:undefined} # not required. list of algorithms that you would accept the certificate to be signed with (e.g. ['sha256WithRSAEncryption', 'sha512WithRSAEncryption']).
selfsigned_version: ${32:3} # not required. Version of the C(selfsigned) certificate. Nowadays it should almost always be C(3).
issuer_strict: ${33:false} # not required. If set to True, the I(issuer) field must contain only these values.
force: ${34:false} # not required. Generate the certificate, even if it already exists.
subject_alt_name_strict: ${35:false} # not required. If set to True, the I(subject_alt_name) extension field must contain only these values.
subject_strict: ${36:false} # not required. If set to True, the I(subject) field must contain only these values.
privatekey_passphrase: ${37:undefined} # not required. The passphrase for the I(privatekey_path).

issuer: ${38:undefined} # not required. Key/value pairs that must be present in the issuer name field of the certificate. If you need to specify more than one value with the same key, use a list as value.
csr_path: ${39:undefined} # not required. Path to the Certificate Signing Request (CSR) used to generate this certificate. This is not required in C(assertonly) mode.
acme_chain: ${40:true} # not required. Include the intermediate certificate to the generated certificate
serole: ${41:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
openssl_csr:
path: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the file into which the generated OpenSSL certificate signing request will be written
privatekey_path: ${2:undefined} # required. Path to the privatekey to use when signing the certificate signing request
seuser: ${3:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
selevel: ${4:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: ${5:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
ocsp_must_staple: ${6:undefined} # not required. Indicates that the certificate should contain the OCSP Must Staple extension (U(https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7633)).

subject: ${7:undefined} # not required. Key/value pairs that will be present in the subject name field of the certificate signing request.,If you need to specify more than one value with the same key, use a list as value.
locality_name: ${8:undefined} # not required. localityName field of the certificate signing request subject
version: ${9:1} # not required. Version of the certificate signing request

ocsp_must_staple_critical: ${10:undefined} # not required. Should the OCSP Must Staple extension be considered as critical,Warning: according to the RFC, this extension should not be marked as critical, as old clients not knowing about OCSP Must Staple are required to reject such certificates (see U(https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7633#section-4)).
organization_name: ${11:undefined} # not required. organizationName field of the certificate signing request subject
subject_alt_name_critical: ${12:undefined} # not required. Should the subjectAltName extension be considered as critical

extended_key_usage: ${13:undefined} # not required. Additional restrictions (e.g. client authentication, server authentication) on the allowed purposes for which the public key may be used.,This can either be a 'comma separated string' or a YAML list.
state_or_province_name: ${14:undefined} # not required. stateOrProvinceName field of the certificate signing request subject
basic_constraints_critical: ${15:undefined} # not required. Should the basicConstraints extension be considered as critical
group: ${16:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

key_usage: ${17:undefined} # not required. This defines the purpose (e.g. encipherment, signature, certificate signing) of the key contained in the certificate.,This can either be a 'comma separated string' or a YAML list.
serole: ${18:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
country_name: ${19:undefined} # not required. countryName field of the certificate signing request subject

subject_alt_name: ${20:undefined} # not required. SAN extension to attach to the certificate signing request,This can either be a 'comma separated string' or a YAML list.,Values should be prefixed by their options. (i.e., C(email), C(URI), C(DNS), C(RID), C(IP), C(dirName), C(otherName) and the ones specific to your CA),More at U(https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.1.6)
extended_key_usage_critical: ${21:undefined} # not required. Should the extkeyUsage extension be considered as critical
key_usage_critical: ${22:undefined} # not required. Should the keyUsage extension be considered as critical
setype: ${23:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
force: ${24|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Should the certificate signing request be forced regenerated by this ansible module
privatekey_passphrase: ${25:undefined} # not required. The passphrase for the privatekey.
owner: ${26:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

attributes: ${27:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).

unsafe_writes: ${28:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
digest: ${29:sha256} # not required. Digest used when signing the certificate signing request with the private key
basic_constraints: ${30:undefined} # not required. Indicates basic constraints, such as if the certificate is a CA.
state: ${31|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the certificate signing request should exist or not, taking action if the state is different from what is stated.
email_address: ${32:undefined} # not required. emailAddress field of the certificate signing request subject
common_name: ${33:undefined} # not required. commonName field of the certificate signing request subject
organizational_unit_name: ${34:undefined} # not required. organizationalUnitName field of the certificate signing request subject
openssl_dhparam:
path: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the file in which the generated parameters will be saved.
size: ${2:4096} # not required. Size (in bits) of the generated DH-params
selevel: ${3:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
force: ${4|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Should the parameters be regenerated even it it already exists
serole: ${5:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
owner: ${6:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
setype: ${7:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: ${8:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).

attributes: ${9:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
seuser: ${10:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
state: ${11|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the parameters should exist or not, taking action if the state is different from what is stated.
group: ${12:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

unsafe_writes: ${13:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
openssl_privatekey:
path: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the file in which the generated TLS/SSL private key will be written. It will have 0600 mode.
size: ${2:4096} # not required. Size (in bits) of the TLS/SSL key to generate
type: ${3|RSA,DSA|} # not required. choices: RSA;DSA. The algorithm used to generate the TLS/SSL private key
force: ${4|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Should the key be regenerated even it it already exists
serole: ${5:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
owner: ${6:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
passphrase: ${7:undefined} # not required. The passphrase for the private key.
setype: ${8:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: ${9:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).

attributes: ${10:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
seuser: ${11:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
state: ${12|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the private key should exist or not, taking action if the state is different from what is stated.
selevel: ${13:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
cipher: ${14:undefined} # not required. The cipher to encrypt the private key. (cipher can be found by running `openssl list-cipher-algorithms`)
group: ${15:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

unsafe_writes: ${16:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.

openssl_publickey.description: Generate an OpenSSL public key from its private key.
body: openssl_publickey:
path: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the file in which the generated TLS/SSL public key will be written.
privatekey_path: ${2:undefined} # required. Path to the TLS/SSL private key from which to generate the public key.
selevel: ${3:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
force: ${4|true,false|} # not required. choices: true;false. Should the key be regenerated even it it already exists

unsafe_writes: ${5:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
format: ${6|PEM,OpenSSH|} # not required. choices: PEM;OpenSSH. The format of the public key.
serole: ${7:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
owner: ${8:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

mode: ${9:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
setype: ${10:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
privatekey_passphrase: ${11:undefined} # not required. The passphrase for the privatekey.

attributes: ${12:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
seuser: ${13:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
state: ${14|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the public key should exist or not, taking action if the state is different from what is stated.
group: ${15:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
openvswitch_bridge:
bridge: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of bridge or fake bridge to manage
external_ids: ${2:None} # not required. A dictionary of external-ids. Omitting this parameter is a No-op. To  clear all external-ids pass an empty value.
fail_mode: ${3|secure,standalone|} # not required. choices: secure;standalone. Set bridge fail-mode. The default value (None) is a No-op.
vlan: ${4:None} # not required. The VLAN id of the fake bridge to manage (must be between 0 and 4095). This parameter is required if I(parent) parameter is set.
parent: ${5:None} # not required. Bridge parent of the fake bridge to manage
set: ${6:None} # not required. Run set command after bridge configuration. This parameter is non-idempotent, play will always return I(changed) state if present
timeout: ${7:5} # not required. How long to wait for ovs-vswitchd to respond
state: ${8|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the bridge should exist
openvswitch_db:
col: ${1:undefined} # required. Identifies the column in the record.
value: ${2:undefined} # required. Expected value for the table, record, column and key.
table: ${3:undefined} # required. Identifies the table in the database.
key: ${4:undefined} # required. Identifies the key in the record column
record: ${5:undefined} # required. Identifies the recoard in the table.
timeout: ${6:5} # not required. How long to wait for ovs-vswitchd to respond

state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Configures the state of the key. When set to I(present), the I(key) and I(value) pair will be set on the I(record) and when set to I(absent) the I(key) will not be set.
openvswitch_port:
bridge: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of bridge to manage
port: ${2:undefined} # required. Name of port to manage on the bridge
set: ${3:None} # not required. Set a single property on a port.
external_ids: ${4:[object Object]} # not required. Dictionary of external_ids applied to a port.
timeout: ${5:5} # not required. How long to wait for ovs-vswitchd to respond
state: ${6|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the port should exist
tag: ${7:undefined} # not required. VLAN tag for this port. Must be a value between 0 and 4095.
openwrt_init:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the service.
enabled: ${2|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. Whether the service should start on boot. B(At least one of state and enabled are required.)

state: ${3|started,stopped,restarted,reloaded|} # not required. choices: started;stopped;restarted;reloaded. C(started)/C(stopped) are idempotent actions that will not run commands unless necessary. C(restarted) will always bounce the service. C(reloaded) will always reload.

pattern: ${4:undefined} # not required. If the service does not respond to the 'running' command, name a substring to look for as would be found in the output of the I(ps) command as a stand-in for a 'running' result.  If the string is found, the service will be assumed to be running.
opkg:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. name of package to install/remove
update_cache: ${2|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. update the package db first
state: ${3|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. state of the package

force: ${4|,depends,maintainer,reinstall,overwrite,downgrade,space,postinstall,remove,checksum,removal-of-dependent-packages|} # not required. choices: ;depends;maintainer;reinstall;overwrite;downgrade;space;postinstall;remove;checksum;removal-of-dependent-packages. opkg --force parameter used
ordnance_config:

defaults: ${1|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. This argument specifies whether or not to collect all defaults when getting the remote device running config.  When enabled, the module will get the current config by issuing the command C(show running-config all).

save: ${2|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running- config to the startup-config at the conclusion of the module running.  If check mode is specified, this argument is ignored.

backup: ${3|yes,no|} # not required. choices: yes;no. This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

multiline_delimiter: ${4:@} # not required. This argument is used when pushing a multiline configuration element to the Ordnance router.  It specifies the character to use as the delimiting character.  This only applies to the configuration action

replace: ${5|line,block|} # not required. choices: line;block. Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.

src: ${6:null} # not required. Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines), I(parents).

match: ${7|line,strict,exact,none|} # not required. choices: line;strict;exact;none. Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

after: ${8:null} # not required. The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

config: ${9:null} # not required. The C(config) argument allows the playbook designer to supply the base configuration to be used to validate configuration changes necessary.  If this argument is provided, the module will not download the running-config from the remote node.

before: ${10:null} # not required. The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

lines: ${11:null} # not required. The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

parents: ${12:null} # not required. The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section or hierarchy the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

ordnance_facts.description: Collect facts from Ordnance Virtual Routers over SSH
body: ordnance_facts:

gather_subset: ${1:!config} # not required. When supplied, this argument will restrict the facts collected to a given subset.  Possible values for this argument include all, hardware, config, and interfaces.  Can specify a list of values to include a larger subset.  Values can also be used with an initial C(M(!)) to specify that a specific subset should not be collected.
os_auth:
api_timeout: ${1:undefined} # not required. How long should the socket layer wait before timing out for API calls. If this is omitted, nothing will be passed to the requests library.
interface: ${2|public,internal,admin|} # not required. choices: public;internal;admin. Endpoint URL type to fetch from the service catalog.
cert: ${3:undefined} # not required. A path to a client certificate to use as part of the SSL transaction.
verify: ${4:undefined} # not required. Whether or not SSL API requests should be verified. Before 2.3 this defaulted to True.
cacert: ${5:undefined} # not required. A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL API requests.
key: ${6:undefined} # not required. A path to a client key to use as part of the SSL transaction.
region_name: ${7:undefined} # not required. Name of the region.
wait: ${8:true} # not required. Should ansible wait until the requested resource is complete.

cloud: ${9:undefined} # not required. Named cloud or cloud config to operate against. If I(cloud) is a string, it references a named cloud config as defined in an OpenStack clouds.yaml file. Provides default values for I(auth) and I(auth_type). This parameter is not needed if I(auth) is provided or if OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present. If I(cloud) is a dict, it contains a complete cloud configuration like would be in a section of clouds.yaml.
availability_zone: ${10:undefined} # not required. Ignored. Present for backwards compatibility

auth_type: ${11:undefined} # not required. Name of the auth plugin to use. If the cloud uses something other than password authentication, the name of the plugin should be indicated here and the contents of the I(auth) parameter should be updated accordingly.
timeout: ${12:180} # not required. How long should ansible wait for the requested resource.

auth: ${13:undefined} # not required. Dictionary containing auth information as needed by the cloud's auth plugin strategy. For the default I(password) plugin, this would contain I(auth_url), I(username), I(password), I(project_name) and any information about domains if the cloud supports them. For other plugins, this param will need to contain whatever parameters that auth plugin requires. This parameter is not needed if a named cloud is provided or OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present.
os_client_config:
clouds: ${1:} # not required. List of clouds to limit the return list to. No value means return information on all configured clouds

os_flavor_facts.description: Retrieve facts about one or more flavors
body: os_flavor_facts:
interface: ${1|public,internal,admin|} # not required. choices: public;internal;admin. Endpoint URL type to fetch from the service catalog.
api_timeout: ${2:undefined} # not required. How long should the socket layer wait before timing out for API calls. If this is omitted, nothing will be passed to the requests library.
availability_zone: ${3:undefined} # not required. Ignored. Present for backwards compatibility

ram: ${4:false} # not required. A string used for filtering flavors based on the amount of RAM (in MB) desired. This string accepts the following special values: 'MIN' (return flavors with the minimum amount of RAM), and 'MAX' (return flavors with the maximum amount of RAM).,A specific amount of RAM may also be specified. Any flavors with this exact amount of RAM will be returned.,A range of acceptable RAM may be given using a special syntax. Simply prefix the amount of RAM with one of these acceptable range values: '<', '>', '<=', '>='. These values represent less than, greater than, less than or equal to, and greater than or equal to, respectively.
cert: ${5:undefined} # not required. A path to a client certificate to use as part of the SSL transaction.
verify: ${6:undefined} # not required. Whether or not SSL API requests should be verified. Before 2.3 this defaulted to True.
limit: ${7:None} # not required. Limits the number of flavors returned. All matching flavors are returned by default.
cacert: ${8:undefined} # not required. A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL API requests.
key: ${9:undefined} # not required. A path to a client key to use as part of the SSL transaction.
region_name: ${10:undefined} # not required. Name of the region.
ephemeral: ${11:false} # not required. A string used for filtering flavors based on the amount of ephemeral storage. Format is the same as the I(ram) parameter
vcpus: ${12:false} # not required. A string used for filtering flavors based on the number of virtual CPUs desired. Format is the same as the I(ram) parameter.

auth: ${13:undefined} # not required. Dictionary containing auth information as needed by the cloud's auth plugin strategy. For the default I(password) plugin, this would contain I(auth_url), I(username), I(password), I(project_name) and any information about domains if the cloud supports them. For other plugins, this param will need to contain whatever parameters that auth plugin requires. This parameter is not needed if a named cloud is provided or OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present.
wait: ${14:true} # not required. Should ansible wait until the requested resource is complete.

cloud: ${15:undefined} # not required. Named cloud or cloud config to operate against. If I(cloud) is a string, it references a named cloud config as defined in an OpenStack clouds.yaml file. Provides default values for I(auth) and I(auth_type). This parameter is not needed if I(auth) is provided or if OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present. If I(cloud) is a dict, it contains a complete cloud configuration like would be in a section of clouds.yaml.
timeout: ${16:180} # not required. How long should ansible wait for the requested resource.

auth_type: ${17:undefined} # not required. Name of the auth plugin to use. If the cloud uses something other than password authentication, the name of the plugin should be indicated here and the contents of the I(auth) parameter should be updated accordingly.
name: ${18:None} # not required. A flavor name. Cannot be used with I(ram) or I(vcpus) or I(ephemeral).

os_floating_ip.description: Add/Remove floating IP from an instance
body: os_floating_ip:
server: ${1:undefined} # required. The name or ID of the instance to which the IP address should be assigned.
interface: ${2|public,internal,admin|} # not required. choices: public;internal;admin. Endpoint URL type to fetch from the service catalog.
api_timeout: ${3:undefined} # not required. How long should the socket layer wait before timing out for API calls. If this is omitted, nothing will be passed to the requests library.
fixed_address: ${4:undefined} # not required. To which fixed IP of server the floating IP address should be attached to.
availability_zone: ${5:undefined} # not required. Ignored. Present for backwards compatibility
purge: ${6:false} # not required. When I(state) is absent, indicates whether or not to delete the floating IP completely, or only detach it from the server. Default is to detach only.

reuse: ${7:false} # not required. When I(state) is present, and I(floating_ip_address) is not present, this parameter can be used to specify whether we should try to reuse a floating IP address already allocated to the project.

auth_type: ${8:undefined} # not required. Name of the auth plugin to use. If the cloud uses something other than password authentication, the name of the plugin should be indicated here and the contents of the I(auth) parameter should be updated accordingly.
verify: ${9:undefined} # not required. Whether or not SSL API requests should be verified. Before 2.3 this defaulted to True.
cacert: ${10:undefined} # not required. A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL API requests.
key: ${11:undefined} # not required. A path to a client key to use as part of the SSL transaction.
region_name: ${12:undefined} # not required. Name of the region.
cert: ${13:undefined} # not required. A path to a client certificate to use as part of the SSL transaction.

floating_ip_address: ${14:undefined} # not required. A floating IP address to attach or to detach. Required only if I(state) is absent. When I(state) is present can be used to specify a IP address to attach.

auth: ${15:undefined} # not required. Dictionary containing auth information as needed by the cloud's auth plugin strategy. For the default I(password) plugin, this would contain I(auth_url), I(username), I(password), I(project_name) and any information about domains if the cloud supports them. For other plugins, this param will need to contain whatever parameters that auth plugin requires. This parameter is not needed if a named cloud is provided or OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present.
wait: ${16:false} # not required. When attaching a floating IP address, specify whether we should wait for it to appear as attached.

cloud: ${17:undefined} # not required. Named cloud or cloud config to operate against. If I(cloud) is a string, it references a named cloud config as defined in an OpenStack clouds.yaml file. Provides default values for I(auth) and I(auth_type). This parameter is not needed if I(auth) is provided or if OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present. If I(cloud) is a dict, it contains a complete cloud configuration like would be in a section of clouds.yaml.
timeout: ${18:60} # not required. Time to wait for an IP address to appear as attached. See wait.
state: ${19|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Should the resource be present or absent.
network: ${20:undefined} # not required. The name or ID of a neutron external network or a nova pool name.
nat_destination: ${21:None} # not required. The name or id of a neutron private network that the fixed IP to attach floating IP is on
os_group:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Group name
interface: ${2|public,internal,admin|} # not required. choices: public;internal;admin. Endpoint URL type to fetch from the service catalog.
api_timeout: ${3:undefined} # not required. How long should the socket layer wait before timing out for API calls. If this is omitted, nothing will be passed to the requests library.
domain_id: ${4:None} # not required. Domain id to create the group in if the cloud supports domains.
availability_zone: ${5:undefined} # not required. Ignored. Present for backwards compatibility
description: ${6:None} # not required. Group description
cert: ${7:undefined} # not required. A path to a client certificate to use as part of the SSL transaction.
verify: ${8:undefined} # not required. Whether or not SSL API requests should be verified. Before 2.3 this defaulted to True.
cacert: ${9:undefined} # not required. A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL API requests.
key: ${10:undefined} # not required. A path to a client key to use as part of the SSL transaction.
region_name: ${11:undefined} # not required. Name of the region.

auth: ${12:undefined} # not required. Dictionary containing auth information as needed by the cloud's auth plugin strategy. For the default I(password) plugin, this would contain I(auth_url), I(username), I(password), I(project_name) and any information about domains if the cloud supports them. For other plugins, this param will need to contain whatever parameters that auth plugin requires. This parameter is not needed if a named cloud is provided or OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present.
wait: ${13:true} # not required. Should ansible wait until the requested resource is complete.

cloud: ${14:undefined} # not required. Named cloud or cloud config to operate against. If I(cloud) is a string, it references a named cloud config as defined in an OpenStack clouds.yaml file. Provides default values for I(auth) and I(auth_type). This parameter is not needed if I(auth) is provided or if OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present. If I(cloud) is a dict, it contains a complete cloud configuration like would be in a section of clouds.yaml.
timeout: ${15:180} # not required. How long should ansible wait for the requested resource.
state: ${16|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Should the resource be present or absent.

auth_type: ${17:undefined} # not required. Name of the auth plugin to use. If the cloud uses something other than password authentication, the name of the plugin should be indicated here and the contents of the I(auth) parameter should be updated accordingly.
os_image:
name: ${1:None} # required. Name that has to be given to the image
interface: ${2|public,internal,admin|} # not required. choices: public;internal;admin. Endpoint URL type to fetch from the service catalog.
availability_zone: ${3:undefined} # not required. Ignored. Present for backwards compatibility
cert: ${4:undefined} # not required. A path to a client certificate to use as part of the SSL transaction.
wait: ${5:true} # not required. Should ansible wait until the requested resource is complete.
cacert: ${6:undefined} # not required. A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL API requests.
key: ${7:undefined} # not required. A path to a client key to use as part of the SSL transaction.
region_name: ${8:undefined} # not required. Name of the region.
checksum: ${9:None} # not required. The checksum of the image
is_public: ${10:yes} # not required. Whether the image can be accessed publicly. Note that publicizing an image requires admin role by default.
kernel: ${11:None} # not required. The name of an existing kernel image that will be associated with this image
container_format: ${12:bare} # not required. The format of the container
disk_format: ${13:qcow2} # not required. The format of the disk that is getting uploaded

cloud: ${14:undefined} # not required. Named cloud or cloud config to operate against. If I(cloud) is a string, it references a named cloud config as defined in an OpenStack clouds.yaml file. Provides default values for I(auth) and I(auth_type). This parameter is not needed if I(auth) is provided or if OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present. If I(cloud) is a dict, it contains a complete cloud configuration like would be in a section of clouds.yaml.

auth_type: ${15:undefined} # not required. Name of the auth plugin to use. If the cloud uses something other than password authentication, the name of the plugin should be indicated here and the contents of the I(auth) parameter should be updated accordingly.
ramdisk: ${16:None} # not required. The name of an existing ramdisk image that will be associated with this image
min_disk: ${17:None} # not required. The minimum disk space (in GB) required to boot this image
properties: ${18:[object Object]} # not required. Additional properties to be associated with this image
api_timeout: ${19:undefined} # not required. How long should the socket layer wait before timing out for API calls. If this is omitted, nothing will be passed to the requests library.
verify: ${20:undefined} # not required. Whether or not SSL API requests should be verified. Before 2.3 this defaulted to True.
min_ram: ${21:None} # not required. The minimum ram (in MB) required to boot this image
id: ${22:None} # not required. The Id of the image
filename: ${23:None} # not required. The path to the file which has to be uploaded
owner: ${24:None} # not required. The owner of the image
timeout: ${25:180} # not required. How long should ansible wait for the requested resource.
state: ${26|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Should the resource be present or absent.

auth: ${27:undefined} # not required. Dictionary containing auth information as needed by the cloud's auth plugin strategy. For the default I(password) plugin, this would contain I(auth_url), I(username), I(password), I(project_name) and any information about domains if the cloud supports them. For other plugins, this param will need to contain whatever parameters that auth plugin requires. This parameter is not needed if a named cloud is provided or OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present.

os_image_facts.description: Retrieve facts about an image within OpenStack.
body: os_image_facts:
image: ${1:undefined} # required. Name or ID of the image
api_timeout: ${2:undefined} # not required. How long should the socket layer wait before timing out for API calls. If this is omitted, nothing will be passed to the requests library.
interface: ${3|public,internal,admin|} # not required. choices: public;internal;admin. Endpoint URL type to fetch from the service catalog.
cert: ${4:undefined} # not required. A path to a client certificate to use as part of the SSL transaction.
verify: ${5:undefined} # not required. Whether or not SSL API requests should be verified. Before 2.3 this defaulted to True.
cacert: ${6:undefined} # not required. A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL API requests.
key: ${7:undefined} # not required. A path to a client key to use as part of the SSL transaction.
region_name: ${8:undefined} # not required. Name of the region.
wait: ${9:true} # not required. Should ansible wait until the requested resource is complete.

cloud: ${10:undefined} # not required. Named cloud or cloud config to operate against. If I(cloud) is a string, it references a named cloud config as defined in an OpenStack clouds.yaml file. Provides default values for I(auth) and I(auth_type). This parameter is not needed if I(auth) is provided or if OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present. If I(cloud) is a dict, it contains a complete cloud configuration like would be in a section of clouds.yaml.
availability_zone: ${11:undefined} # not required. Ignored. Present for backwards compatibility

auth_type: ${12:undefined} # not required. Name of the auth plugin to use. If the cloud uses something other than password authentication, the name of the plugin should be indicated here and the contents of the I(auth) parameter should be updated accordingly.
timeout: ${13:180} # not required. How long should ansible wait for the requested resource.

auth: ${14:undefined} # not required. Dictionary containing auth information as needed by the cloud's auth plugin strategy. For the default I(password) plugin, this would contain I(auth_url), I(username), I(password), I(project_name) and any information about domains if the cloud supports them. For other plugins, this param will need to contain whatever parameters that auth plugin requires. This parameter is not needed if a named cloud is provided or OpenStack OS_* environment variables are present.

os_ironic.description: Create/Delete Bare Metal Resources from OpenStack
body: os_ironic:
driver: ${1:None} # required. The name of the Ironic Driver to use with this node.
nics: ${2:undefined} # required. A list of network interface cards, eg, " - mac: aa:bb:cc:aa:bb:cc"
