group: ${20:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
follow: ${21:no} # not required. This flag indicates that filesystem links in the destination, if they exist, should be followed.,Previous to Ansible 2.4, this was hardcoded as C(yes).
terraform:
project_path: ${1:undefined} # required. The path to the root of the Terraform directory with the vars.tf/main.tf/etc to use.
lock: ${2:undefined} # not required. Enable statefile locking, if you use a service that accepts locks (such as S3+DynamoDB) to store your statefile.
state: ${3|planned,present,absent|} # not required. choices: planned;present;absent. Goal state of given stage/project

state_file: ${4:undefined} # not required. The path to an existing Terraform state file to use when building plan. If this is not specified, the default `terraform.tfstate` will be used.,This option is ignored when plan is specified.
variables: ${5:undefined} # not required. A group of key-values to override template variables or those in variables files.
binary_path: ${6:undefined} # not required. The path of a terraform binary to use, relative to the 'service_path' unless you supply an absolute path.

force_init: ${7:false} # not required. To avoid duplicating infra, if a state file can't be found this will force a `terraform init`. Generally, this should be turned off unless you intend to provision an entirely new Terraform deployment.
lock_timeout: ${8:undefined} # not required. How long to maintain the lock on the statefile, if you use a service that accepts locks (such as S3+DynamoDB).
plan_file: ${9:undefined} # not required. The path to an existing Terraform plan file to apply. If this is not specified, Ansible will build a new TF plan and execute it.
targets: ${10:undefined} # not required. A list of specific resources to target in this plan/application. The resources selected here will also auto-include any dependencies.
variables_file: ${11:undefined} # not required. The path to a variables file for Terraform to fill into the TF configurations.
timezone:

hwclock: ${1:undefined} # not required. Whether the hardware clock is in UTC or in local timezone. Default is to keep current setting. Note that this option is recommended not to change and may fail to configure, especially on virtual environments such as AWS. B(At least one of name and hwclock are required.) I(Only used on Linux.)
name: ${2:undefined} # not required. Name of the timezone for the system clock. Default is to keep current setting. B(At least one of name and hwclock are required.)

tower_credential.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower credential.
body: tower_credential:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. The name to use for the credential.

kind: ${2|ssh,vault,net,scm,aws,vmware,satellite6,cloudforms,gce,azure_rm,openstack,rhv,insights,tower|} # required. choices: ssh;vault;net;scm;aws;vmware;satellite6;cloudforms;gce;azure_rm;openstack;rhv;insights;tower. Type of credential being added.
ssh_key_data: ${3:null} # not required. Path to SSH private key.

tower_verify_ssl: ${4:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_password: ${5:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
tower_host: ${6:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
team: ${7:null} # not required. Team that should own this credential.
organization: ${8:null} # not required. Organization that should own the credential.
vault_password: ${9:undefined} # not required. Valut password. Use ASK for prompting.
subscription: ${10:null} # not required. Subscription ID for azure_rm type.
become_method: ${11|None,sudo,su,pbrun,pfexec,pmrun|} # not required. choices: None;sudo;su;pbrun;pfexec;pmrun. Become method to Use for privledge escalation.
description: ${12:undefined} # not required. The description to use for the credential.
host: ${13:null} # not required. Host for this credential.
client: ${14:null} # not required. Client or application ID for azure_rm type.
secret: ${15:null} # not required. Secret token for azure_rm type.
become_password: ${16:null} # not required. Become password. Use ASK for prompting.
ssh_key_unlock: ${17:undefined} # not required. Unlock password for ssh_key. Use ASK for prompting.
password: ${18:null} # not required. Password for this credential. Use ASK for prompting. secret_key for AWS. api_key for RAX.
tower_username: ${19:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
domain: ${20:null} # not required. Domain for openstack type.
become_username: ${21:null} # not required. Become username. Use ASK for prompting.
authorize_password: ${22:null} # not required. Password for net credentials that require authroize.
tenant: ${23:null} # not required. Tenant ID for azure_rm type.
user: ${24:null} # not required. User that should own this credential.
tower_config_file: ${25:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
project: ${26:null} # not required. Project that should for this credential.
authorize: ${27:false} # not required. Should use authroize for net type.
state: ${28|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.
username: ${29:null} # not required. Username for this credential. access_key for AWS.

tower_group.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower group.
body: tower_group:
inventory: ${1:undefined} # required. Inventory the group should be made a member of.
name: ${2:undefined} # required. The name to use for the group.
credential: ${3:null} # not required. Credential to use for the group.
tower_username: ${4:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
description: ${5:null} # not required. The description to use for the group.
tower_host: ${6:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
instance_filters: ${7:null} # not required. Comma-separated list of filter expressions for matching hosts.
overwrite_vars: ${8:null} # not required. Override vars in child groups and hosts with those from external source.
variables: ${9:null} # not required. Variables to use for the group, use '@' for a file.
source_vars: ${10:null} # not required. Override variables from source with variables from this field.
source_regions: ${11:null} # not required. Regions for cloud provider.
update_on_launch: ${12:false} # not required. Refresh inventory data from its source each time a job is run.
overwrite: ${13:false} # not required. Delete child roups and hosts not found in source.
tower_password: ${14:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
source_script: ${15:null} # not required. Inventory script to be used when group type is "custom".
tower_config_file: ${16:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.

source: ${17|manual,file,ec2,rax,vmware,gce,azure,azure_rm,openstack,satellite6,cloudforms,custom|} # not required. choices: manual;file;ec2;rax;vmware;gce;azure;azure_rm;openstack;satellite6;cloudforms;custom. The source to use for this group.
state: ${18|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.
group_by: ${19:null} # not required. Limit groups automatically created from inventory source.

tower_verify_ssl: ${20:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

tower_host.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower host.
body: tower_host:
inventory: ${1:undefined} # required. Inventory the host should be made a member of.
name: ${2:undefined} # required. The name to use for the host.
tower_host: ${3:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
enabled: ${4:true} # not required. If the host should be enabled.
tower_username: ${5:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
description: ${6:null} # not required. The description to use for the host.
tower_password: ${7:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
variables: ${8:undefined} # not required. Variables to use for the host. Use '@' for a file.
state: ${9|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_verify_ssl: ${10:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_config_file: ${11:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.

tower_inventory.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower inventory.
body: tower_inventory:
organization: ${1:undefined} # required. Organization the inventory belongs to.
name: ${2:undefined} # required. The name to use for the inventory.
tower_host: ${3:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${4:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
description: ${5:null} # not required. The description to use for the inventory.
tower_config_file: ${6:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
tower_password: ${7:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
variables: ${8:null} # not required. Inventory variables. Use '@' to get from file.
state: ${9|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_verify_ssl: ${10:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_job_cancel:
job_id: ${1:undefined} # required. ID of the job to cancel
tower_host: ${2:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.

tower_verify_ssl: ${3:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_config_file: ${4:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
fail_if_not_running: ${5:false} # not required. Fail loudly if the job_id does not reference a running job.
tower_password: ${6:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${7:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
tower_job_launch:
job_template: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the job_template to use.
credential: ${2:null} # not required. Credential to use for job, only used if prompt for credential is set.
job_explanation: ${3:null} # not required. Job explanation field.
inventory: ${4:null} # not required. Inventory to use for the job, only used if prompt for inventory is set.
use_job_endpoint: ${5:false} # not required. Disable launching jobs from job template.
tags: ${6:null} # not required. Specific tags to use for from playbook.
tower_password: ${7:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
limit: ${8:null} # not required. Limit to use for the job_template.
extra_vars: ${9:null} # not required. Extra_vars to use for the job_template. Prepend '@' if a file.

tower_verify_ssl: ${10:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_username: ${11:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
job_type: ${12|run,check,scan|} # not required. choices: run;check;scan. Job_type to use for the job, only used if prompt for job_type is set.
tower_config_file: ${13:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
tower_host: ${14:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_job_list:
all_pages: ${1:false} # not required. Fetch all the pages and return a single result.
page: ${2:null} # not required. Page number of the results to fetch.

tower_verify_ssl: ${3:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
query: ${4:null} # not required. Query used to further filter the list of jobs. {"foo":"bar"} will be passed at ?foo=bar
tower_host: ${5:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_password: ${6:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${7:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
status: ${8|pending,waiting,running,error,failed,canceled,successful|} # not required. choices: pending;waiting;running;error;failed;canceled;successful. Only list jobs with this status.
tower_config_file: ${9:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.

tower_job_template.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower job_template.
body: tower_job_template:
playbook: ${1:undefined} # required. Playbook to use for the job_template.
job_type: ${2|run,check,scan|} # required. choices: run;check;scan. The job_type to use for the job_template.
name: ${3:undefined} # required. Name to use for the job_template.
project: ${4:undefined} # required. Project to use for the job_template.
skip_tags: ${5:null} # not required. The skip_tags to use for the job_template.
ask_tags: ${6:false} # not required. Prompt user for job tags on launch.
become_enabled: ${7:false} # not required. Should become_enabled.
tower_password: ${8:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
cloud_credential: ${9:null} # not required. Cloud_credential to use for the job_template.
limit: ${10:null} # not required. A host pattern to further constrain the list of hosts managed or affected by the playbook
network_credential: ${11:null} # not required. The network_credential to use for the job_template.
ask_job_type: ${12:false} # not required. Prompt user for job type on launch.
ask_credential: ${13:false} # not required. Prompt user for credential on launch.
description: ${14:null} # not required. Description to use for the job_template.
tower_host: ${15:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
job_tags: ${16:null} # not required. The job_tags to use for the job_template.
verbosity: ${17|verbose,debug|} # not required. choices: verbose;debug. Control the output level Ansible produces as the playbook runs.
inventory: ${18:null} # not required. Inventory to use for the job_template.
machine_credential: ${19:null} # not required. Machine_credential to use for the job_template.
tower_username: ${20:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
host_config_key: ${21:null} # not required. Allow provisioning callbacks using this host config key.
extra_vars_path: ${22:null} # not required. Path to the extra_vars yaml file.
ask_inventory: ${23:false} # not required. Propmt user for inventory on launch.
forks: ${24:null} # not required. The number of parallel or simultaneous processes to use while executing the playbook.
state: ${25|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_verify_ssl: ${26:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
ask_extra_vars: ${27:false} # not required. Prompt user for extra_vars on launch.
tower_config_file: ${28:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.

tower_job_wait.description: Wait for Ansible Tower job to finish.
body: tower_job_wait:
job_id: ${1:undefined} # required. ID of the job to monitor.
tower_host: ${2:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
max_interval: ${3:30} # not required. Maximum interval in seconds, to request an update from Tower.
tower_username: ${4:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
tower_password: ${5:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
timeout: ${6:null} # not required. Maximum time in seconds to wait for a job to finish.
min_interval: ${7:1} # not required. Minimum interval in seconds, to request an update from Tower.

tower_verify_ssl: ${8:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_config_file: ${9:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.

tower_label.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower label.
body: tower_label:
organization: ${1:null} # required. Organization the label should be applied to.
name: ${2:null} # required. Name to use for the label.
tower_host: ${3:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${4:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: ${5:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
tower_password: ${6:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_verify_ssl: ${8:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

tower_organization.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower organizations
body: tower_organization:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name to use for the organization.
tower_host: ${2:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${3:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
description: ${4:null} # not required. The description to use for the organization.
tower_config_file: ${5:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
tower_password: ${6:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_verify_ssl: ${8:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

tower_project.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower projects
body: tower_project:
name: ${1:null} # required. Name to use for the project.

tower_verify_ssl: ${2:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
description: ${3:null} # not required. Description to use for the project.
scm_clean: ${4:false} # not required. Remove local modifications before updating.
tower_password: ${5:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${6:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
organization: ${7:null} # not required. Primary key of organization for project.
scm_type: ${8|manual,git,hg,svn|} # not required. choices: manual;git;hg;svn. Type of scm resource.
scm_branch: ${9:null} # not required. The branch to use for the scm resource.
tower_host: ${10:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
scm_update_on_launch: ${11:false} # not required. Before an update to the local repository before launching a job with this project.
scm_credential: ${12:null} # not required. Name of the credential to use with this scm resource.
tower_config_file: ${13:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
scm_delete_on_update: ${14:false} # not required. Remove the repository completely before updating.
state: ${15|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.
local_path: ${16:null} # not required. The server playbook directory for manual projects.
scm_url: ${17:null} # not required. URL of scm resource.

tower_role.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower role.
body: tower_role:
role: ${1|admin,read,member,execute,adhoc,update,use,auditor|} # required. choices: admin;read;member;execute;adhoc;update;use;auditor. The role type to grant/revoke.
credential: ${2:null} # not required. Credential the role acts on.
team: ${3:null} # not required. Team that receives the permissions specified by the role.
inventory: ${4:null} # not required. Inventory the role acts on.
tower_password: ${5:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
target_team: ${6:null} # not required. Team that the role acts on.
organization: ${7:null} # not required. Organiation the role acts on.

tower_verify_ssl: ${8:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_host: ${9:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
user: ${10:null} # not required. User that receives the permissions specified by the role.
tower_username: ${11:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: ${12:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
project: ${13:null} # not required. Project the role acts on.
job_template: ${14:null} # not required. The job_template the role acts on.
state: ${15|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_team.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower team.
body: tower_team:
organization: ${1:null} # required. Organization the team should be made a member of.
name: ${2:null} # required. Name to use for the team.
tower_host: ${3:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${4:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.

tower_password: ${6:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
state: ${7|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Desired state of the resource.

tower_verify_ssl: ${8:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

tower_user.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower user.
body: tower_user:
email: ${1:undefined} # required. Email address of the user.
username: ${2:undefined} # required. The username of the user.

tower_verify_ssl: ${3:true} # not required. Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
password: ${4:null} # not required. Password of the user.
tower_password: ${5:null} # not required. Password for your Tower instance.
tower_host: ${6:null} # not required. URL to your Tower instance.
tower_username: ${7:null} # not required. Username for your Tower instance.
first_name: ${8:null} # not required. First name of the user.
tower_config_file: ${9:null} # not required. Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
superuser: ${10:false} # not required. User is a system wide administator.

twilio.description: Sends a text message to a mobile phone through Twilio.
body: twilio:
account_sid: ${1:undefined} # required. user's Twilio account token found on the account page
msg: ${2:undefined} # required. the body of the text message
from_number: ${3:undefined} # required. the Twilio number to send the text message from, format +15551112222
to_number: ${4:undefined} # required. one or more phone numbers to send the text message to, format +15551112222
auth_token: ${5:undefined} # required. user's Twilio authentication token
media_url: ${6:undefined} # not required. a URL with a picture, video or sound clip to send with an MMS (multimedia message) instead of a plain SMS
typetalk:
msg: ${1:undefined} # required. message body
topic: ${2:undefined} # required. topic id to post message
client_secret: ${3:undefined} # required. OAuth2 client secret
client_id: ${4:undefined} # required. OAuth2 client ID

ucs_ip_pool.description: Configures IP address pools on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_ip_pool:
hostname: ${1:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${2:undefined} # required. The name of the IP address pool.,This name can be between 1 and 32 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the IP address pool is created.
password: ${3:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.

order: ${4|default,sequential|} # not required. choices: default;sequential. The Assignment Order field.,This can be one of the following:,default - Cisco UCS Manager selects a random identity from the pool.,sequential - Cisco UCS Manager selects the lowest available identity from the pool.
ipv6_secondary_dns: ${5:::} # not required. The secondary DNS server that this block of IPv6 addresses should access.
port: ${6:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).
ipv6_first_addr: ${7:undefined} # not required. The first IPv6 address in the IPv6 addresses block.,This is the From field in the UCS Manager Add IPv6 Blocks menu.
proxy: ${8:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
ipv6_prefix: ${9:64} # not required. The network address prefix associated with the IPv6 addresses in the block.
secondary_dns: ${10:0.0.0.0} # not required. The secondary DNS server that this block of IPv4 addresses should access.
use_proxy: ${11:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.
last_addr: ${12:undefined} # not required. The last IPv4 address in the IPv4 addresses block.,This is the To field in the UCS Manager Add IPv4 Blocks menu.
subnet_mask: ${13:255.255.255.0} # not required. The subnet mask associated with the IPv4 addresses in the block.
org_dn: ${14:org-root} # not required. Org dn (distinguished name)
primary_dns: ${15:0.0.0.0} # not required. The primary DNS server that this block of IPv4 addresses should access.
ipv6_primary_dns: ${16:::} # not required. The primary DNS server that this block of IPv6 addresses should access.

descrption: ${17:undefined} # not required. The user-defined description of the IP address pool.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).
ipv6_default_gw: ${18:::} # not required. The default gateway associated with the IPv6 addresses in the block.
first_addr: ${19:undefined} # not required. The first IPv4 address in the IPv4 addresses block.,This is the From field in the UCS Manager Add IPv4 Blocks menu.
default_gw: ${20:0.0.0.0} # not required. The default gateway associated with the IPv4 addresses in the block.

state: ${21|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify IP pool is present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify IP pool is absent and will delete if needed.
username: ${22:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
ipv6_last_addr: ${23:undefined} # not required. The last IPv6 address in the IPv6 addresses block.,This is the To field in the UCS Manager Add IPv6 Blocks menu.
use_ssl: ${24:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_lan_connectivity.description: Configures LAN Connectivity Policies on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_lan_connectivity:
password: ${1:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
hostname: ${2:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${3:undefined} # required. The name of the LAN Connectivity Policy.,This name can be between 1 and 16 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the policy is created.
org_dn: ${4:org-root} # not required. Org dn (distinguished name)

description: ${5:undefined} # not required. A description of the LAN Connectivity Policy.,Cisco recommends including information about where and when to use the policy.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).
port: ${6:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).
proxy: ${7:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'

vnic_list: ${8:undefined} # not required. List of vNICs used by the LAN Connectivity Policy.,vNICs used by the LAN Connectivity Policy must be created from a vNIC template.,Each list element has the following suboptions:,= name,  The name of the vNIC (required).,= vnic_template,  The name of the vNIC template (required).,- adapter_policy,  The name of the Ethernet adapter policy.,  A user defined policy can be used, or one of the system defined policies.,- order,  String specifying the vNIC assignment order (e.g., '1', '2').,  [Default: unspecified]
use_proxy: ${9:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify LAN Connectivity Policies are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify LAN Connectivity Policies are absent and will delete if needed.
username: ${11:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
use_ssl: ${12:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_mac_pool.description: Configures MAC address pools on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_mac_pool:
password: ${1:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
hostname: ${2:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${3:undefined} # required. The name of the MAC pool.,This name can be between 1 and 32 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the MAC pool is created.

order: ${4|default,sequential|} # not required. choices: default;sequential. The Assignment Order field.,This can be one of the following:,default - Cisco UCS Manager selects a random identity from the pool.,sequential - Cisco UCS Manager selects the lowest available identity from the pool.
org_dn: ${5:org-root} # not required. The distinguished name (dn) of the organization where the resource is assigned.
username: ${6:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
port: ${7:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).

descrption: ${8:undefined} # not required. A description of the MAC pool.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).
first_addr: ${9:undefined} # not required. The first MAC address in the block of addresses.,This is the From field in the UCS Manager MAC Blocks menu.
proxy: ${10:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${11:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

state: ${12|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify MAC pool is present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify MAC pool is absent and will delete if needed.
last_addr: ${13:undefined} # not required. The last MAC address in the block of addresses.,This is the To field in the UCS Manager Add MAC Blocks menu.
use_ssl: ${14:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_san_connectivity.description: Configures SAN Connectivity Policies on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_san_connectivity:
password: ${1:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
hostname: ${2:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${3:undefined} # required. The name of the SAN Connectivity Policy.,This name can be between 1 and 16 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the policy is created.

vhba_list: ${4:undefined} # not required. List of vHBAs used by the SAN Connectivity Policy.,vHBAs used by the SAN Connectivity Policy must be created from a vHBA template.,Each list element has the following suboptions:,= name,  The name of the virtual HBA (required).,= vhba_template,  The name of the virtual HBA template (required).,- adapter_policy,  The name of the Fibre Channel adapter policy.,  A user defined policy can be used, or one of the system defined policies (default, Linux, Solaris, VMware, Windows, WindowsBoot),  [Default: default],- order,  String specifying the vHBA assignment order (e.g., '1', '2').,  [Default: unspecified]

state: ${5|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify SAN Connectivity Policies are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify SAN Connectivity Policies are absent and will delete if needed.

description: ${6:undefined} # not required. A description of the policy.,Cisco recommends including information about where and when to use the policy.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).
port: ${7:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).
org_dn: ${8:org-root} # not required. Org dn (distinguished name)
proxy: ${9:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${10:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.
wwnn_pool: ${11:default} # not required. Name of the WWNN pool to use for WWNN assignment.
username: ${12:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
use_ssl: ${13:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_vhba_template.description: Configures vHBA templates on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_vhba_template:
password: ${1:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
hostname: ${2:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${3:undefined} # required. The name of the virtual HBA template.,This name can be between 1 and 16 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the template is created.

redundancy_type: ${4|none,primary,secondary|} # not required. choices: none;primary;secondary. The Redundancy Type used for template pairing from the Primary or Secondary redundancy template.,primary — Creates configurations that can be shared with the Secondary template.,Any other shared changes on the Primary template are automatically synchronized to the Secondary template.,secondary — All shared configurations are inherited from the Primary template.,none - Legacy vHBA template behavior. Select this option if you do not want to use redundancy.
pin_group: ${5:undefined} # not required. The SAN pin group that is associated with vHBAs created from this template.

description: ${6:undefined} # not required. A user-defined description of the template.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).

template_type: ${7|initial-template,updating-template|} # not required. choices: initial-template;updating-template. The Template Type field.,This can be one of the following:,initial-template — vHBAs created from this template are not updated if the template changes.,updating-template - vHBAs created from this template are updated if the template changes.
qos_policy: ${8:undefined} # not required. The QoS policy that is associated with vHBAs created from this template.
port: ${9:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).
wwpn_pool: ${10:default} # not required. The WWPN pool that a vHBA created from this template uses to derive its WWPN address.
stats_policy: ${11:default} # not required. The statistics collection policy that is associated with vHBAs created from this template.
max_data: ${12:2048} # not required. The Max Data Field Size field.,The maximum size of the Fibre Channel frame payload bytes that the vHBA supports.,Enter an string between '256' and '2112'.
org_dn: ${13:org-root} # not required. Org dn (distinguished name)
vsan: ${14:default} # not required. The VSAN to associate with vHBAs created from this template.
proxy: ${15:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${16:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

state: ${17|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify vHBA templates are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify vHBA templates are absent and will delete if needed.
username: ${18:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
fabric: ${19|A,B|} # not required. choices: A;B. The Fabric ID field.,The name of the fabric interconnect that vHBAs created with this template are associated with.
use_ssl: ${20:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_vlans.description: Configures VLANs on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_vlans:
password: ${1:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.

id: ${2:undefined} # required. The unique string identifier assigned to the VLAN.,A VLAN ID can be between '1' and '3967', or between '4048' and '4093'.,You cannot create VLANs with IDs from 4030 to 4047. This range of VLAN IDs is reserved.,The VLAN IDs you specify must also be supported on the switch that you are using.,VLANs in the LAN cloud and FCoE VLANs in the SAN cloud must have different IDs.,Optional if state is absent.
hostname: ${3:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${4:undefined} # required. The name assigned to the VLAN.,The VLAN name is case sensitive.,This name can be between 1 and 32 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the VLAN is created.

sharing: ${5|none,primary,isolated,community|} # not required. choices: none;primary;isolated;community. The Sharing Type field.,Whether this VLAN is subdivided into private or secondary VLANs. This can be one of the following:,none - This VLAN does not have any secondary or private VLANs. This is a regular VLAN.,primary - This VLAN can have one or more secondary VLANs, as shown in the Secondary VLANs area. This VLAN is a primary VLAN in the private VLAN domain.,isolated - This is a private VLAN associated with a primary VLAN. This VLAN is an Isolated VLAN.,community - This VLAN can communicate with other ports on the same community VLAN as well as the promiscuous port. This VLAN is a Community VLAN.
native: ${6|no,yes|} # not required. choices: no;yes. Designates the VLAN as a native VLAN.
port: ${7:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).

fabric: ${8|common,A,B|} # not required. choices: common;A;B. The fabric configuration of the VLAN.  This can be one of the following:,common - The VLAN applies to both fabrics and uses the same configuration parameters in both cases.,A — The VLAN only applies to fabric A.,B — The VLAN only applies to fabric B.,For upstream disjoint L2 networks, Cisco recommends that you choose common to create VLANs that apply to both fabrics.
proxy: ${9:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${10:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

state: ${11|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify VLANs are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify VLANs are absent and will delete if needed.
username: ${12:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
multicast_policy: ${13:} # not required. The multicast policy associated with this VLAN.,This option is only valid if the Sharing Type field is set to None or Primary.
use_ssl: ${14:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_vnic_template.description: Configures vNIC templates on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_vnic_template:

name: ${1:undefined} # required. The name of the vNIC template.,This name can be between 1 and 16 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the template is created.
hostname: ${2:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.
password: ${3:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.

redundancy_type: ${4|none,primary,secondary|} # not required. choices: none;primary;secondary. The Redundancy Type used for vNIC redundancy pairs during fabric failover.,This can be one of the following:,primary — Creates configurations that can be shared with the Secondary template.,secondary — All shared configurations are inherited from the Primary template.,none - Legacy vNIC template behavior. Select this option if you do not want to use redundancy.
network_control_policy: ${5:undefined} # not required. The network control policy that vNICs created from this vNIC template should use.
pin_group: ${6:undefined} # not required. The LAN pin group that vNICs created from this vNIC template should use.
port: ${7:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).

vlans_list: ${8:undefined} # not required. List of VLANs used by the vNIC template.,Each list element has the following suboptions:,= name,  The name of the VLAN (required).,- native,  Designates the VLAN as a native VLAN.  Only one VLAN in the list can be a native VLAN.,  [choices: 'no', 'yes'],  [Default: 'no']
stats_policy: ${9:default} # not required. The statistics collection policy that vNICs created from this vNIC template should use.

peer_redundancy_template: ${10:undefined} # not required. The Peer Redundancy Template.,The name of the vNIC template sharing a configuration with this template.,If the redundancy_type is primary, the name of the secondary template should be provided.,If the redundancy_type is secondary, the name of the primary template should be provided.,Secondary templates can only configure non-shared properties (name, description, and mac_pool).
proxy: ${11:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${12:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

fabric: ${13|A,B,A-B,B-A|} # not required. choices: A;B;A-B;B-A. The Fabric ID field specifying the fabric interconnect associated with vNICs created from this template.,If you want fabric failover enabled on vNICs created from this template, use of of the following:",A-B to use Fabric A by default with failover enabled.,B-A to use Fabric B by default with failover enabled.,Do not enable vNIC fabric failover under the following circumstances:,- If the Cisco UCS domain is running in Ethernet switch mode. vNIC fabric failover is not supported in that mode.,- If you plan to associate one or more vNICs created from this template to a server with an adapter that does not support fabric failover.

target: ${14:adapter} # not required. The possible target for vNICs created from this template.,The target determines whether or not Cisco UCS Manager automatically creates a VM-FEX port profile with the appropriate settings for the vNIC template.,This can be one of the following:,adapter — The vNICs apply to all adapters. No VM-FEX port profile is created if you choose this option.,vm - The vNICs apply to all virtual machines. A VM-FEX port profile is created if you choose this option.
org_dn: ${15:org-root} # not required. Org dn (distinguished name)

description: ${16:undefined} # not required. A user-defined description of the vNIC template.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).

template_type: ${17|initial-template,updating-template|} # not required. choices: initial-template;updating-template. The Template Type field.,This can be one of the following:,initial-template — vNICs created from this template are not updated if the template changes.,updating-template - vNICs created from this template are updated if the template changes.

mtu: ${18:1500} # not required. The MTU field.,The maximum transmission unit, or packet size, that vNICs created from this vNIC template should use.,Enter a string between '1500' and '9000'.,If the vNIC template has an associated QoS policy, the MTU specified here must be equal to or less than the MTU specified in the QoS system class.
qos_policy: ${19:undefined} # not required. The quality of service (QoS) policy that vNICs created from this vNIC template should use.
mac_pool: ${20:undefined} # not required. The MAC address pool that vNICs created from this vNIC template should use.
cdn_name: ${21:undefined} # not required. CDN Name used when cdn_source is set to user-defined.

cdn_source: ${22|vnic-name,user-defined|} # not required. choices: vnic-name;user-defined. CDN Source field.,This can be one of the following options:,vnic-name - Uses the vNIC template name of the vNIC instance as the CDN name. This is the default option.,user-defined - Uses a user-defined CDN name for the vNIC template. If this option is chosen, cdn_name must also be provided.

state: ${23|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify vNIC templates are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify vNIC templates are absent and will delete if needed.
username: ${24:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
use_ssl: ${25:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_vsans.description: Configures VSANs on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_vsans:

vsan_id: ${1:undefined} # required. The unique identifier assigned to the VSAN.,The ID can be a string between '1' and '4078', or between '4080' and '4093'. '4079' is a reserved VSAN ID.,In addition, if you plan to use FC end-host mode, the range between '3840' to '4079' is also a reserved VSAN ID range.,Optional if state is absent.
password: ${2:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
hostname: ${3:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.

name: ${4:undefined} # required. The name assigned to the VSAN.,This name can be between 1 and 32 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the VSAN is created.

vlan_id: ${5:undefined} # required. The unique string identifier assigned to the VLAN used for Fibre Channel connections.,Note that Cisco UCS Manager uses VLAN '4048'.  See the UCS Manager configuration guide if you want to assign '4048' to a VLAN.,Optional if state is absent.
port: ${6:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).

fc_zoning: ${7|disabled,enabled|} # not required. choices: disabled;enabled. Fibre Channel zoning configuration for the Cisco UCS domain.,Fibre Channel zoning can be set to one of the following values:,disabled — The upstream switch handles Fibre Channel zoning, or Fibre Channel zoning is not implemented for the Cisco UCS domain.,enabled — Cisco UCS Manager configures and controls Fibre Channel zoning for the Cisco UCS domain.,If you enable Fibre Channel zoning, do not configure the upstream switch with any VSANs that are being used for Fibre Channel zoning.
proxy: ${8:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${9:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify VSANs are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify VSANs are absent and will delete if needed.
username: ${11:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.

fabric: ${12|common,A,B|} # not required. choices: common;A;B. The fabric configuration of the VSAN.  This can be one of the following:,common - The VSAN maps to the same VSAN ID in all available fabrics.,A - The VSAN maps to the a VSAN ID that exists only in fabric A.,B - The VSAN maps to the a VSAN ID that exists only in fabric B.
use_ssl: ${13:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

ucs_wwn_pool.description: Configures WWNN or WWPN pools on Cisco UCS Manager
body: ucs_wwn_pool:
password: ${1:undefined} # required. Password for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
hostname: ${2:undefined} # required. IP address or hostname of Cisco UCS Manager.
purpose: ${3|node,port|} # required. choices: node;port. Specify whether this is a node (WWNN) or port (WWPN) pool.,Optional if state is absent.

name: ${4:undefined} # required. The name of the World Wide Node Name (WWNN) or World Wide Port Name (WWPN) pool.,This name can be between 1 and 32 alphanumeric characters.,You cannot use spaces or any special characters other than - (hyphen), "_" (underscore), : (colon), and . (period).,You cannot change this name after the WWNN or WWPN pool is created.

order: ${5|default,sequential|} # not required. choices: default;sequential. The Assignment Order field.,This can be one of the following:,default - Cisco UCS Manager selects a random identity from the pool.,sequential - Cisco UCS Manager selects the lowest available identity from the pool.
org_dn: ${6:org-root} # not required. Org dn (distinguished name)

description: ${7:undefined} # not required. A description of the WWNN or WWPN pool.,Enter up to 256 characters.,You can use any characters or spaces except the following:,` (accent mark),  (backslash), ^ (carat), " (double quote), = (equal sign), > (greater than), < (less than), or ' (single quote).
username: ${8:admin} # not required. Username for Cisco UCS Manager authentication.
port: ${9:undefined} # not required. Port number to be used during connection (by default uses 443 for https and 80 for http connection).
first_addr: ${10:undefined} # not required. The first initiator in the World Wide Name (WWN) block.,This is the From field in the UCS Manager Add WWN Blocks menu.
proxy: ${11:undefined} # not required. If use_proxy is no, specfies proxy to be used for connection. e.g. 'http://proxy.xy.z:8080'
use_proxy: ${12:true} # not required. If C(no), will not use the proxy as defined by system environment variable.

state: ${13|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. If C(present), will verify WWNNs/WWPNs are present and will create if needed.,If C(absent), will verify WWNNs/WWPNs are absent and will delete if needed.

last_addr: ${14:undefined} # not required. The last initiator in the Worlde Wide Name (WWN) block.,This is the To field in the UCS Manager Add WWN Blocks menu.,For WWxN pools, the pool size must be a multiple of ports-per-node + 1.,For example, if there are 7 ports per node, the pool size must be a multiple of 8.,If there are 63 ports per node, the pool size must be a multiple of 64.
use_ssl: ${15:true} # not required. If C(no), an HTTP connection will be used instead of the default HTTPS connection.

udm_dns_record.description: Manage dns entries on a univention corporate server
body: udm_dns_record:

type: ${1|host_record,alias,ptr_record,srv_record,txt_record|} # required. choices: host_record;alias;ptr_record;srv_record;txt_record. Define the record type. C(host_record) is a A or AAAA record, C(alias) is a CNAME, C(ptr_record) is a PTR record, C(srv_record) is a SRV record and C(txt_record) is a TXT record.
zone: ${2:undefined} # required. Corresponding DNS zone for this record, e.g. example.com.
name: ${3:undefined} # required. Name of the record, this is also the DNS record. E.g. www for www.example.com.
data: ${4:} # not required. Additional data for this record, e.g. ['a': '192.0.2.1']. Required if C(state=present).
state: ${5|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the dns record is present or not.

udm_dns_zone.description: Manage dns zones on a univention corporate server
body: udm_dns_zone:
type: ${1|forward_zone,reverse_zone|} # required. choices: forward_zone;reverse_zone. Define if the zone is a forward or reverse DNS zone.
zone: ${2:undefined} # required. DNS zone name, e.g. C(example.com).
expire: ${3:604800} # not required. Specifies the upper limit on the time interval that can elapse before the zone is no longer authoritative.
contact: ${4:} # not required. Contact person in the SOA record.
retry: ${5:1800} # not required. Interval that should elapse before a failed refresh should be retried.
interfaces: ${6:undefined} # not required. List of interface IP addresses, on which the server should response this zone. Required if C(state=present).
ttl: ${7:600} # not required. Minimum TTL field that should be exported with any RR from this zone.
mx: ${8:} # not required. List of MX servers. (Must declared as A or AAAA records).
nameserver: ${9:undefined} # not required. List of appropriate name servers. Required if C(state=present).
state: ${10|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the dns zone is present or not.
refresh: ${11:3600} # not required. Interval before the zone should be refreshed.
udm_group:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the posix group.
description: ${2:undefined} # not required. Group description.
position: ${3:undefined} # not required. define the whole ldap position of the group, e.g. C(cn=g123m-1A,cn=classes,cn=schueler,cn=groups,ou=schule,dc=example,dc=com).
ou: ${4:undefined} # not required. LDAP OU, e.g. school for LDAP OU C(ou=school,dc=example,dc=com).
state: ${5|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the group is present or not.
subpath: ${6:undefined} # not required. Subpath inside the OU, e.g. C(cn=classes,cn=students,cn=groups).

udm_share.description: Manage samba shares on a univention corporate server
body: udm_share:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name
ou: ${2:undefined} # required. Organisational unit, inside the LDAP Base DN.
samba_force_group: ${3:None} # not required. Force group.
subtree_checking: ${4|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Subtree checking.
samba_csc_policy: ${5:manual} # not required. Client-side caching policy.
samba_nt_acl_support: ${6|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. NT ACL support.
samba_write_list: ${7:None} # not required. Restrict write access to these users/groups.
owner: ${8:0} # not required. Directory owner of the share's root directory.
directorymode: ${9:00755} # not required. Permissions for the share's root directory.
samba_directory_mode: ${10:0755} # not required. Directory mode.
samba_msdfs_root: ${11|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. MSDFS root.
samba_force_create_mode: ${12|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Force file mode.
samba_level_2_oplocks: ${13|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Level 2 oplocks.
samba_dos_filemode: ${14|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Users with write access may modify permissions.
samba_block_size: ${15:None} # not required. Blocking size.
sync: ${16:sync} # not required. NFS synchronisation.
samba_inherit_permissions: ${17|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Create files/directories with permissions of the parent directory.
samba_directory_security_mode: ${18:0777} # not required. Directory security mode.
nfs_custom_settings: ${19:} # not required. Option name in exports file.
samba_vfs_objects: ${20:None} # not required. VFS objects.
samba_hosts_allow: ${21:} # not required. Allowed host/network.
samba_security_mode: ${22:0777} # not required. Security mode.
samba_inherit_owner: ${23|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Create files/directories with the owner of the parent directory.
samba_force_security_mode: ${24|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Force security mode.
state: ${25|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the share is present or not.
samba_hosts_deny: ${26:} # not required. Denied host/network.
samba_force_directory_security_mode: ${27|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Force directory security mode.
samba_blocking_locks: ${28|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Blocking locks.
samba_custom_settings: ${29:} # not required. Option name in smb.conf and its value.
nfs_hosts: ${30:} # not required. Only allow access for this host, IP address or network.
samba_hide_unreadable: ${31|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Hide unreadable files/directories.
samba_create_mode: ${32:0744} # not required. File mode.
samba_invalid_users: ${33:None} # not required. Invalid users or groups.
samba_strict_locking: ${34:Auto} # not required. Strict locking.
path: ${35:None} # not required. Directory on the providing server, e.g. C(/home). Required if C(state=present).
samba_browseable: ${36|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Show in Windows network environment.
host: ${37:None} # not required. Host FQDN (server which provides the share), e.g. C({{ ansible_fqdn }}). Required if C(state=present).
samba_force_user: ${38:None} # not required. Force user.
group: ${39:0} # not required. Directory owner group of the share's root directory.
root_squash: ${40|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Modify user ID for root user (root squashing).
samba_fake_oplocks: ${41|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Fake oplocks.
samba_postexec: ${42:None} # not required. Postexec script.
samba_name: ${43:None} # not required. Windows name. Required if C(state=present).
samba_valid_users: ${44:None} # not required. Valid users or groups.
samba_oplocks: ${45|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Oplocks.
samba_hide_files: ${46:None} # not required. Hide files.
samba_writeable: ${47|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Samba write access.
writeable: ${48|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. NFS write access.
samba_inherit_acls: ${49|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Inherit ACLs.
samba_force_directory_mode: ${50|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Force directory mode.
samba_preexec: ${51:None} # not required. Preexec script.
samba_locking: ${52|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Locking.
samba_public: ${53|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Allow anonymous read-only access with a guest user.

udm_user.description: Manage posix users on a univention corporate server
body: udm_user:
username: ${1:undefined} # required. User name
pwd_change_next_login: ${2|0,1|} # not required. choices: 0;1. Change password on next login.
unixhome: ${3:/home/$USERNAME} # not required. Unix home directory
sambahome: ${4:None} # not required. Windows home path, e.g. C('\\$FQDN\$USERNAME').
department_number: ${5:None} # not required. Department number of users business address.
home_telephone_number: ${6:} # not required. List of private telephone numbers.
title: ${7:None} # not required. Title, e.g. C(Prof.).
postcode: ${8:None} # not required. Postal code of users business address.
scriptpath: ${9:None} # not required. Windows logon script.
homedrive: ${10:None} # not required. Windows home drive, e.g. C("H:").
secretary: ${11:} # not required. A list of superiors as LDAP DNs.
display_name: ${12:None} # not required. Display name (not gecos)
employee_type: ${13:None} # not required. Employee type
ou: ${14:} # not required. Organizational Unit inside the LDAP Base DN, e.g. C(school) for LDAP OU C(ou=school,dc=example,dc=com).
mail_alternative_address: ${15:} # not required. List of alternative e-mail addresses.
password: ${16:None} # not required. Password. Required if C(state=present).
mail_home_server: ${17:None} # not required. FQDN of mail server
mail_primary_address: ${18:None} # not required. Primary e-mail address
birthday: ${19:None} # not required. Birthday
firstname: ${20:undefined} # not required. First name. Required if C(state=present).
email: ${21:} # not required. A list of e-mail addresses.
lastname: ${22:undefined} # not required. Last name. Required if C(state=present).
userexpiry: ${23:Today + 1 year} # not required. Account expiry date, e.g. C(1999-12-31).
primary_group: ${24:cn=Domain Users,cn=groups,$LDAP_BASE_DN} # not required. Primary group. This must be the group LDAP DN.
profilepath: ${25:None} # not required. Windows profile directory
update_password: ${26:always} # not required. C(always) will update passwords if they differ. C(on_create) will only set the password for newly created users.
shell: ${27:/bin/bash} # not required. Login shell
room_number: ${28:None} # not required. Room number of users business address.
position: ${29:} # not required. Define the whole position of users object inside the LDAP tree, e.g. C(cn=employee,cn=users,ou=school,dc=example,dc=com).
override_pw_length: ${30:false} # not required. Override password check
employee_number: ${31:None} # not required. Employee number
override_pw_history: ${32:false} # not required. Override password history
street: ${33:None} # not required. Street of users business address.
groups: ${34:} # not required. POSIX groups, the LDAP DNs of the groups will be found with the LDAP filter for each group as $GROUP: C((&(objectClass=posixGroup)(cn=$GROUP))).
city: ${35:None} # not required. City of users business address.
organisation: ${36:None} # not required. Organisation
state: ${37|present,absent|} # not required. choices: present;absent. Whether the user is present or not.
description: ${38:None} # not required. Description (not gecos)
samba_user_workstations: ${39:} # not required. Allow the authentication only on this Microsoft Windows host.
country: ${40:None} # not required. Country of users business address.
pager_telephonenumber: ${41:} # not required. List of pager telephone numbers.
samba_privileges: ${42:} # not required. Samba privilege, like allow printer administration, do domain join.
home_share_path: ${43:None} # not required. Path to home NFS share, inside the homeShare.
subpath: ${44:cn=users} # not required. LDAP subpath inside the organizational unit, e.g. C(cn=teachers,cn=users) for LDAP container C(cn=teachers,cn=users,dc=example,dc=com).
mobile_telephone_number: ${45:} # not required. Mobile phone number
gecos: ${46:None} # not required. GECOS
serviceprovider: ${47:} # not required. Enable user for the following service providers.
home_share: ${48:None} # not required. Home NFS share. Must be a LDAP DN, e.g. C(cn=home,cn=shares,ou=school,dc=example,dc=com).
phone: ${49:} # not required. List of telephone numbers.
ufw:
from_port: ${1:undefined} # not required. Source port.
interface: ${2:undefined} # not required. Specify interface for rule.
route: ${3:undefined} # not required. Apply the rule to routed/forwarded packets.
logging: ${4|true,false,low,medium,high,full|} # not required. choices: true;false;low;medium;high;full. Toggles logging. Logged packets use the LOG_KERN syslog facility.
policy: ${5|allow,deny,reject|} # not required. choices: allow;deny;reject. Change the default policy for incoming or outgoing traffic.
to_port: ${6:undefined} # not required. Destination port.
proto: ${7|any,tcp,udp,ipv6,esp,ah|} # not required. choices: any;tcp;udp;ipv6;esp;ah. TCP/IP protocol.
name: ${8:undefined} # not required. Use profile located in C(/etc/ufw/applications.d).
delete: ${9:undefined} # not required. Delete rule.
rule: ${10|allow,deny,limit,reject|} # not required. choices: allow;deny;limit;reject. Add firewall rule
from_ip: ${11:any} # not required. Source IP address.
log: ${12:undefined} # not required. Log new connections matched to this rule
insert: ${13:undefined} # not required. Insert the corresponding rule as rule number NUM
comment: ${14:undefined} # not required. Add a comment to the rule. Requires UFW version >=0.35.

state: ${15|disabled,enabled,reloaded,reset|} # not required. choices: disabled;enabled;reloaded;reset. C(enabled) reloads firewall and enables firewall on boot.,C(disabled) unloads firewall and disables firewall on boot.,C(reloaded) reloads firewall.,C(reset) disables and resets firewall to installation defaults.
to_ip: ${16:any} # not required. Destination IP address.
direction: ${17|in,incoming,out,outgoing,routed|} # not required. choices: in;incoming;out;outgoing;routed. Select direction for a rule or default policy command.

unarchive.description: Unpacks an archive after (optionally) copying it from the local machine.
body: unarchive:
dest: ${1:undefined} # required. Remote absolute path where the archive should be unpacked.

src: ${2:undefined} # required. If C(remote_src=no) (default), local path to archive file to copy to the target server; can be absolute or relative. If C(remote_src=yes), path on the target server to existing archive file to unpack.,If C(remote_src=yes) and C(src) contains C(://), the remote machine will download the file from the URL first. (version_added 2.0). This is only for simple cases, for full download support use the M(get_url) module.

validate_certs: ${3:yes} # not required. This only applies if using a https URL as the source of the file.,This should only set to C(no) used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificate.,Prior to 2.2 the code worked as if this was set to C(yes).
selevel: ${4:s0} # not required. Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
creates: ${5:undefined} # not required. If the specified absolute path (file or directory) already exists, this step will B(not) be run.

mode: ${6:null} # not required. Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like C(0644) or C(01777)). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).

copy: ${7:yes} # not required. If true, the file is copied from local 'master' to the target machine, otherwise, the plugin will look for src archive at the target machine.,This option has been deprecated in favor of C(remote_src).,This option is mutually exclusive with C(remote_src).

remote_src: ${8:no} # not required. Set to C(yes) to indicate the archived file is already on the remote system and not local to the Ansible controller.,This option is mutually exclusive with C(copy).
exclude: ${9:undefined} # not required. List the directory and file entries that you would like to exclude from the unarchive action.
decrypt: ${10:Yes} # not required. This option controls the autodecryption of source files using vault.
setype: ${11:null} # not required. Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
list_files: ${12:no} # not required. If set to True, return the list of files that are contained in the tarball.
owner: ${13:null} # not required. Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

attributes: ${14:None} # not required. Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
serole: ${15:null} # not required. Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
group: ${16:null} # not required. Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
seuser: ${17:null} # not required. User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
extra_opts: ${18:} # not required. Specify additional options by passing in an array.
keep_newer: ${19:no} # not required. Do not replace existing files that are newer than files from the archive.

unsafe_writes: ${20:false} # not required. Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.

uptimerobot.description: Pause and start Uptime Robot monitoring
body: uptimerobot:
monitorid: ${1||} # required. choices: . ID of the monitor to check.
state: ${2|started,paused|} # required. choices: started;paused. Define whether or not the monitor should be running or paused.
apikey: ${3||} # required. choices: . Uptime Robot API key.
uri:
url: ${1:undefined} # required. HTTP or HTTPS URL in the form (http|https)://host.domain[:port]/path

validate_certs: ${2:yes} # not required. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated.  This should only set to C(no) used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.  Prior to 1.9.2 the code defaulted to C(no).
removes: ${3:undefined} # not required. a filename, when it does not exist, this step will not be run.
creates: ${4:undefined} # not required. a filename, when it already exists, this step will not be run.

method: ${5|GET,POST,PUT,HEAD,DELETE,OPTIONS,PATCH,TRACE,CONNECT,REFRESH|} # not required. choices: GET;POST;PUT;HEAD;DELETE;OPTIONS;PATCH;TRACE;CONNECT;REFRESH. The HTTP method of the request or response. It MUST be uppercase.

force_basic_auth: ${6:no} # not required. The library used by the uri module only sends authentication information when a webservice responds to an initial request with a 401 status. Since some basic auth services do not properly send a 401, logins will fail. This option forces the sending of the Basic authentication header upon initial request.

follow_redirects: ${7|all,safe,none|} # not required. choices: all;safe;none. Whether or not the URI module should follow redirects. C(all) will follow all redirects. C(safe) will follow only "safe" redirects, where "safe" means that the client is only doing a GET or HEAD on the URI to which it is being redirected. C(none) will not follow any redirects. Note that C(yes) and C(no) choices are accepted for backwards compatibility, where C(yes) is the equivalent of C(all) and C(no) is the equivalent of C(safe). C(yes) and C(no) are deprecated and will be removed in some future version of Ansible.
status_code: ${8:200} # not required. A valid, numeric, HTTP status code that signifies success of the request. Can also be comma separated list of status codes.

client_key: ${9:undefined} # not required. PEM formatted file that contains your private key to be used for SSL client authentication. If I(client_cert) contains both the certificate and key, this option is not required.

client_cert: ${10:undefined} # not required. PEM formatted certificate chain file to be used for SSL client authentication. This file can also include the key as well, and if the key is included, I(client_key) is not required

body_format: ${11|raw,json|} # not required. choices: raw;json. The serialization format of the body. When set to json, encodes the body argument, if needed, and automatically sets the Content-Type header accordingly. As of C(2.3) it is possible to override the `Content-Type` header, when set to json via the I(headers) option.
timeout: ${12:30} # not required. The socket level timeout in seconds

return_content: ${13:no} # not required. Whether or not to return the body of the response as a "content" key in the dictionary result. If the reported Content-type is "application/json", then the JSON is additionally loaded into a key called C(json) in the dictionary results.
dest: ${14:undefined} # not required. path of where to download the file to (if desired). If I(dest) is a directory, the basename of the file on the remote server will be used.
password: ${15:undefined} # not required. password for the module to use for Digest, Basic or WSSE authentication.

HEADER_: ${16:undefined} # not required. Any parameter starting with "HEADER_" is a sent with your request as a header. For example, HEADER_Content-Type="application/json" would send the header "Content-Type" along with your request with a value of "application/json". This option is deprecated as of C(2.1) and will be removed in Ansible-2.9. Use I(headers) instead.
user: ${17:undefined} # not required. username for the module to use for Digest, Basic or WSSE authentication.
others: ${18:undefined} # not required. all arguments accepted by the M(file) module also work here

body: ${19:undefined} # not required. The body of the http request/response to the web service. If C(body_format) is set to 'json' it will take an already formatted JSON string or convert a data structure into JSON.

headers: ${20:undefined} # not required. Add custom HTTP headers to a request in the format of a YAML hash. As of C(2.3) supplying C(Content-Type) here will override the header generated by supplying C(json) for I(body_format).
urpmi:
pkg: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of package to install, upgrade or remove.
root: ${2:/} # not required. Specifies an alternative install root, relative to which all packages will be installed. Corresponds to the C(--root) option for I(urpmi).
update_cache: ${3:no} # not required. Update the package database first C(urpmi.update -a).
force: ${4:yes} # not required. Assume "yes" is the answer to any question urpmi has to ask. Corresponds to the C(--force) option for I(urpmi).
state: ${5|absent,present|} # not required. choices: absent;present. Indicates the desired package state.
no-recommends: ${6:yes} # not required. Corresponds to the C(--no-recommends) option for I(urpmi).
user:
name: ${1:undefined} # required. Name of the user to create, remove or modify.

local: ${2:no} # not required. Forces the use of "local" command alternatives on platforms that implement it. This is useful in environments that use centralized authentification when you want to manipulate the local users. I.E. it uses `luseradd` instead of `useradd`.,This requires that these commands exist on the targeted host, otherwise it will be a fatal error.

create_home: ${3:yes} # not required. Unless set to C(no), a home directory will be made for the user when the account is created or if the home directory does not exist.,Changed from C(createhome) to C(create_home) in version 2.5.
uid: ${4:undefined} # not required. Optionally sets the I(UID) of the user.
ssh_key_bits: ${5:default set by ssh-keygen} # not required. Optionally specify number of bits in SSH key to create.
expires: ${6:undefined} # not required. An expiry time for the user in epoch, it will be ignored on platforms that do not support this. Currently supported on Linux, FreeBSD, and DragonFlyBSD.

groups: ${7:undefined} # not required. Puts the user in  list of groups. When set to the empty string ('groups='), the user is removed from all groups except the primary group.,Before version 2.3, the only input format allowed was a 'comma separated string', now it should be able to accept YAML lists also.
ssh_key_passphrase: ${8:undefined} # not required. Set a passphrase for the SSH key.  If no passphrase is provided, the SSH key will default to having no passphrase.
seuser: ${9:undefined} # not required. Optionally sets the seuser type (user_u) on selinux enabled systems.
group: ${10:undefined} # not required. Optionally sets the user's primary group (takes a group name).
home: ${11:undefined} # not required. Optionally set the user's home directory.
state: ${12|absent,present|} # not required. choices: absent;present. Whether the account should exist or not, taking action if the state is different from what is stated.
non_unique: ${13:no} # not required. Optionally when used with the -u option, this option allows to change the user ID to a non-unique value.
force: ${14:no} # not required. When used with C(state=absent), behavior is as with C(userdel --force).
move_home: ${15:no} # not required. If set to C(yes) when used with C(home=), attempt to move the user's home directory to the specified directory if it isn't there already.
system: ${16:no} # not required. When creating an account, setting this to C(yes) makes the user a system account.  This setting cannot be changed on existing users.

password: ${17:undefined} # not required. Optionally set the user's password to this crypted value.  See the user example in the github examples directory for what this looks like in a playbook. See U(http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/faq.html#how-do-i-generate-crypted-passwords-for-the-user-module) for details on various ways to generate these password values. Note on Darwin system, this value has to be cleartext. Beware of security issues.
ssh_key_type: ${18:rsa} # not required. Optionally specify the type of SSH key to generate. Available SSH key types will depend on implementation present on target host.
skeleton: ${19:undefined} # not required. Optionally set a home skeleton directory. Requires create_home option!
ssh_key_comment: ${20:ansible-generated on $HOSTNAME} # not required. Optionally define the comment for the SSH key.
remove: ${21:no} # not required. When used with C(state=absent), behavior is as with C(userdel --remove).
ssh_key_file: ${22:.ssh/id_rsa} # not required. Optionally specify the SSH key filename. If this is a relative filename then it will be relative to the user's home directory.
login_class: ${23:undefined} # not required. Optionally sets the user's login class for FreeBSD, DragonFlyBSD, OpenBSD and NetBSD systems.
